[[Image:Chrysler Building Midtown Manhattan New York City 1932.jpg|thumb|right|300px|Midtown Manhattan in 1932, showing the results of the Zoning Resolution: skyscrapers with [[Setback (architecture)|setbacks]]]]
The '''1916 Zoning Resolution''' in [[New York City]] was the first citywide zoning code in the US. The zoning resolution reflected both borough and local interests, and was proposed after the development of 120 Broadway (the [[Equitable Building (Manhattan)|Equitable Building]]) in [[lower Manhattan]]. It was a measure adopted primarily to stop massive buildings from preventing light and air from reaching the streets below, and established limits in building [[massing]] at certain heights, usually interpreted as a series of [[Setback (architecture)|setbacks]] and, while not imposing height limits, restricted towers to a percentage of the lot size. The chief authors of this resolution were [[George McAneny]] and [[Edward M. Bassett]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Dunlap|first1=David W.|author-link1=David W. Dunlap|title=Zoning Arrived 100 Years Ago. It Changed New York City Forever.|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/07/26/nyregion/new-yorks-first-zoning-resolution-which-brought-order-to-a-chaotic-building-boom-turns-100.html?_r=0|date=July 26, 2016|newspaper = [[The New York Times]]}}</ref>
==Impact== The 1916 Zoning Resolution had a major impact on [[urban development]] in the US and internationally.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www1.nyc.gov/site/planning/zoning/background.page|title=Background|website=www1.nyc.gov|access-date=2017-05-24}}</ref> Architectural delineator [[Hugh Ferriss]] popularized these new regulations in 1922 through a series of massing studies, clearly depicting the possible forms and how to maximize building volumes. "By the end of the 1920s the setback skyscraper, originally built in response to a New York zoning code, became a style that caught on from Chicago to Shanghai," observe Eric Peter Nash and Norman McGrath,<ref>Nash and McGrath, ''Manhattan Skyscrapers'' 2005:55.</ref> discussing the [[Williamsburgh Savings Bank Building]], which rose in isolation in [[Brooklyn]], where no such zoning dictated form. The tiered [[Art Deco]] skyscrapers of the 1920s and 1930s are a direct result of this resolution.
==Legacy== By mid-century most new [[International Style (architecture)|International Style]] buildings had met the setback requirements by adopting the use of plazas or low-rise buildings surrounding a monolithic tower centered on the site. This approach was criticized.<ref>{{cite news | last = Dunlap | first = David W. | title = At New Trade Center, Seeking Lively (but Secure) Streets | newspaper = The New York Times | date = December 7, 2006 | url = https://www.nytimes.com/2006/12/07/nyregion/07blocks.html | accessdate = 2008-06-06}}</ref>
In 1961 the city reformed its zoning ordinance. The new zoning solution used the [[Floor Area Ratio]] (FAR) regulation instead of setback rules. A building’s maximum floor area is regulated according to the ratio that was imposed to the site where the building is located. Another feature of new zoning solution was adjacent public open space. If developers put adjacent public open space to their buildings, they could get additional area for their building as a bonus. This incentive bonus rule was created because of the strong influence from two representative skyscrapers. The [[Seagram building]] by [[Mies van der Rohe]] with [[Philip Johnson]], and the [[Lever House]] by [[Skidmore, Owings & Merrill]] introduced the new ideas about office building with open space. These buildings changed the skyline of New York City with both the advent of simple glass box design and their treatment of adjacent open spaces. The new zoning encouraged privately owned public space to ease the density of the city.<ref>W. Bressi, Todd (1993). Planning and Zoning New York City. Rutgers, the State University of New Jersey. pp. 9–12.</ref>

{{Other uses|Blips (disambiguation)}} '''BLIPS''' is an [[acronym]] for ''Bond Linked Issue Premium Structure'', or ''Bond Linked Investment Premium Strategy''. It is a type of tax shelter involving investors who take out bank loans that the government considers illegitimate. These loans are then shifted to partnerships to claim tax losses.<ref>Lynnley Browning, Judge Rules a Tax Shelter in KPMG Case Is Legitimate, ''[[The New York Times]]'', July 21, 2006.</ref>
BLIPS are invalid in the eyes of the [[Internal Revenue Service]] (IRS).<ref>''Vaughn v. United States IRS'', 765 F.3d 1174, 1177 (10th Cir. 2014).</ref>
==History== BLIPS represent one of four abusive tax shelters that the [[Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations]] investigated in 2003. The Subcomittee found that [[KPMG]] had sold to at least 350 people from 1997 to 2001, earning fees of $124 million. Those shelters cost the Treasury at least $1.4 billion in unpaid taxes, according to the subcommittee. In the investigation, KPMG argued that investors knew they were taking a risk that the IRS might not accept the claims.<ref>''Becnel v. KPMG LLP'', 387 F. Supp. 2d 984, 2005-2 U.S. Tax Cas. (CCH) paragr. 50,573 (W.D. Ark. 2005) (Federal court had subject matter jurisdiction, based on "substantial federal question," in connection with controversy removed from Arkansas state court to Federal district court).</ref>

{{Use dmy dates|date=June 2013}} {{Refimprove|September 2010|date=September 2010}} The '''British and Irish Association of Law Librarians''' ('''BIALL,''' http://www.biall.org.uk/) is a professional body which represents information professionals working with legal information. BIALL is a self-supporting association which draws its income primarily from membership subscriptions.
== History == BIALL was set up in 1969 following workshops on law librarianship held at [[Harrogate]] in 1968 and 1969. Two strands led to the formation of BIALL. Firstly, the law librarians in London, Oxford, Cambridge and Ireland had been in contact and working together since the late 1940s, reinforced by their membership of the International Association of Law Librarians (IALL).<ref>[http://www.iall.org/ International Association of Law Librarians]</ref> Secondly, the outreach programme of [[Leeds Polytechnic|Leeds Library School]] led to one of the School’s staff, Don Daintree, organising Workshops on Law Librarianship in Harrogate in 1968 and 1969. They brought together the foremost law library figures as speakers and those few people who were working in law libraries as students of the Workshops. The inspiration for the Workshops was the [[Chartered Institute of Library and Information Professionals|Library Association]]’s List C papers on the bibliography and librarianship of subjects.
The 1st Harrogate Workshop in February was held at the Russell Hotel and a meeting at the end of the Workshop set up an ad hoc Committee to look into the possibility of establishing an association of law librarians. Committee members were [[Wallace Breem]], Don Daintree, [[Betty Moys]], Willi Steiner and Derek Way. The 2nd Harrogate Workshop in April concluded with a meeting which set up an Association of Law Librarians. This was the inaugural meeting and those who were present are BIALL’s founder members. The first AGM was held in a basement room of the old IALS building in [[Russell Square]] on Monday 22 September. It was chaired by Willi Steiner, several hours were spent debating the minutiae of the draft Constitution. One of the decisions was to form a separate organisation, not affiliated to, or part of, the Library Association, resulting from strong arguments that organisations (especially law firms) who had no professional librarians, would be excluded from membership if the Association were part of the LA. The principle of welcoming professionally qualified and non-qualified law librarians into BIALL has prevailed ever since.
The first officers were Don Daintree (Chairman), [[Wallace Breem]] (Secretary and Treasurer) and Betty Moys (Editor). An Executive Committee was subsequently elected and in November it set up a Sub-Committee of Betty Moys, Allan Appleby of [[Sweet and Maxwell]], and [[Wallace Breem]] to produce a journal.
== BIALL Conference ==
BIALL organises an annual Conference<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://biall.org.uk/annual-conference/|title=BIALL Conference|last=|first=|date=|website=BIALL|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=10 April 2018}}</ref> every year which all BIALL members are invited to attend. The Conference is an opportunity to listen to talks delivered by Legal Information Professionals and Industry experts as well as network with colleagues. The most recent Conference took place in [[Birmingham]] on 7th-9th June 2018, with the next conference (the 50th anniversary of both the organisation, and the conference) taking place in [[Bournemouth]] in June 2019.
Previous Conferences have taken place in [[Manchester]] (2017), [[Dublin]] (2016), [[Brighton]] (2015), [[Harrogate]] (2014), [[Glasgow]] (2013), [[Belfast]] (2012), [[Gateshead]] (2011), [[Brighton]] (2010), [[Manchester]] (2009), [[Dublin]] (2008), [[Sheffield]] (2007), [[Brighton]] (2006), [[Harrogate]] (2005), [[Edinburgh]] (2004), and [[Cardiff]] (2003).
== Awards and other activities ==
BIALL administers and presents several awards at its annual conference dinner including the BIALL Supplier of the Year Award, the LexisLibrary Awards (formerly the Halsbury's Awards), the biannual [[Wallace Breem]] Award, the [[Betty Moys]] Award, the Legal Journals Award, and the Wildy Law Librarian of the Year Award.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://biall.org.uk/awards-2/|title=BIALL Awards|last=|first=|date=|website=BIALL|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=10 April 2018}}</ref>
== Publications == Legal Information Management http://journals.cambridge.org/action/displayJournal?jid=LIM
[http://www.biall.org.uk/pages/handbook-of-legal-information-management-2nd-edition.html Handbook of Legal Information Management], 2nd ed (2014)
[http://www.biall.org.uk/publications.php?action=publication&id=33 Moys Classification and Thesaurus for Legal Materials] (2012)

{{Use mdy dates|date=June 2014}} [[File:0703 SD orca squirt.jpg|thumb|300px|right|Orca show at Sea World San Diego]]
'''Captive killer whales''' are live [[killer whales]] (Orcinus orca) which are held in [[Captivity (animal)|captivity]] by humans, often for breeding or performance purposes. The practice of capturing and displaying these whales in exhibitions began in the 1960s, soon becoming popular attractions at [[public aquarium]]s and [[marine mammal park|aquatic theme parks]] due to their intelligence, trainability, striking appearance, playfulness, and sheer size. As of September, 2016, there were 56 [[List of captive orcas|orcas in captivity worldwide]], 33 of which are captive-born.<ref>[http://us.whales.org/wdc-in-action/fate-of-captive-orcas-in-2014 The Fate of Captive Orcas in 2014]</ref> There are 13 live orcas in the Seaworld parks.{{citation needed|date=May 2018}}
The practice of keeping killer whales in captivity is controversial, due to the separation of their familial "pod" during capture, and their living conditions and health in captivity.<ref name="Orcas in captivity">{{cite web|url=http://www.wdcs.org/dan/publishing.nsf/allweb/A141A8A02A2FE3C7802568F60029D1F9 |title=Orcas in captivity |publisher=Whale and Dolphin Conservation Society |accessdate=July 25, 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070805220554/http://www.wdcs.org/dan/publishing.nsf/allweb/A141A8A02A2FE3C7802568F60029D1F9 |archivedate=August 5, 2007 }}</ref> There have been 4 human deaths involving orcas as of 2018, 3 of which involved a whale called [[Tilikum (orca)|Tilikum]]. Of the reported [[killer whale attack|killer whale attacks]] in the wild, none have been fatal.
==Orcas== {{Main|Killer whale}} [[File:Killerwhales jumping.jpg|thumb|right|250px| Transient orcas near [[Unimak Island]], eastern Aleutian Islands, Alaska]]
Killer whales are large, active and intelligent. Males range from {{Convert|6|to|9.7|m|0|abbr=on}} and weigh over {{Convert|8|tonne}}, while females range from {{Convert|5|to|7|m|abbr=on}} and weigh {{Convert|3|to|5|tonne}}.<ref name=Baird2002>{{Cite book|last=Baird|first=Robin W|year=2002|title=Killer whales of the world: natural history and conservation|isbn=0-89658-512-3|publisher=Voyageur Press|location=Stillwater, Minnesota}}</ref> The killer whale (''Orcinus orca'') is the largest species of the Dolphin family. The species is found in all the world's oceans, from the frigid [[Arctic]] and [[Antarctica|Antarctic]] regions to warm, tropical seas. Killer whales are intelligent, versatile and opportunistic predators. Some populations feed mostly on fish, and other populations hunt [[marine mammals]], including [[sea lion]]s, [[Earless seal|seals]], [[walruses]], [[dolphin]]s, large [[whale]]s and some species of shark. They are considered an [[apex predator]], as no animal predates on them. There are up to five distinct killer whale types, some of which may be separate [[race (biology)|races]], [[subspecies]] or even [[species]].{{Citation needed|date=March 2015}}<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.nmfs.noaa.gov/pr/species/mammals/whales/killer-whale.html|title=Killer whale ''(Orcinus orca)'' :: NOAA Fisheries|last=Fisheries|first=NOAA|website=www.nmfs.noaa.gov|language=en-us|access-date=2016-09-29}}</ref> Killer whales are highly [[social animal|social]]; some populations are composed of [[matrilineal]] family groups, which are the most stable of any animal species.<ref name=Balcomb2000>{{cite book|last=Balcomb|first=C. Kenneth|year=2000|title=Killer whales: the natural history and genealogy of ''Orcinus orca'' in British Columbia and Washington State|isbn=0-7748-0800-4|publisher=UBC Press|location=Vancouver}}</ref> The sophisticated social behavior, hunting techniques, and vocal behavior of killer whales have been described as manifestations of [[animal culture]].<ref name=martin>{{cite web|url=http://discovermagazine.com/1993/dec/killerculture322|title=Killer Culture|author=Glen Martin|date=December 1, 1993|publisher=DISCOVER Magazine|accessdate=December 14, 2007}}</ref>
Although killer whales are not an [[endangered species]], some local populations are [[Threatened species|threatened]] or [[endangered species|endangered]] due to [[bioaccumulation]] of [[Polychlorinated biphenyl|PCBs]] pollution, depletion of prey species, captures for marine mammal parks, [[cetacean bycatch|conflicts with fishing activities]], [[Marine mammals and sonar|acoustic pollution]], [[ship strike|shipping vessels]], stress from [[whale-watching]] boats, and habitat loss.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2004/mar/02/nation/na-orcas2 |title=Washington Officials Say Orcas Threatened |publisher=Articles.latimes.com |date=March 2, 2004 |accessdate=April 29, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://captivekillerwhales.tumblr.com/|title=Captive killer whales}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=Canada Dot Com |url=http://article.wn.com/view/2008/10/08/Killer_whales_threatened_by_salmon_shortage/ |title=Killer whales threatened by salmon shortage |publisher=Article.wn.com |date= |accessdate=April 29, 2014}}</ref>
==Capture and breeding== It is extremely difficult to capture killer whales and to provide a healthy environment for the captives. Early attempts in the 1960s caused many injuries and deaths. However, with experience the teams who specialized in the business became more adept and post-capture survival rates improved. Live captures peaked in the early 1970s, but have become increasingly rare as the marine parks have learned how to maintain theme park populations through captive breeding and artificial insemination.
===North Eastern Pacific captures=== [[File:Orca dorsalfin NOAA.JPG|300px|The [[dorsal fin]] and [[saddle patch]] of a killer whale known as Sonora or sometimes Holly (A42) of the [[List of northern resident killer whale pods|Northern Resident Orcas]]|thumb|right]]
The first capture in the North Eastern Pacific occurred in November 1961. A collecting crew from [[Marineland of the Pacific]] in [[Los Angeles, California|Los Angeles]], took the {{Convert|5.2|m|adj=on|abbr=on}} orca to a tank at the aquarium, where she repeatedly crashed into the walls. She was named Wanda and died the following day.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://newspaperarchive.com/independent-press-telegram/1961-11-19/?tag=killer+whale+wanda&rtserp=tags/?plo=killer-whale-wanda/|title=Killer Whale Netted in Newport Harbor|publisher=Independent-Press-Telegram Newspaper of Long Beach, California / Bob Geivet|date=November 19, 1961|accessdate=February 25, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.marinelandofthepacific.org/animalcollection/killerwhales.html |title='Newport Specimen' November, 1961 / Behavioral, Antatomical and Pathological Data on the 'Newport Specimen' |publisher=Marineland of the Pacific Historical Society |date= |accessdate=February 25, 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140407200527/http://www.marinelandofthepacific.org/animalcollection/killerwhales.html |archivedate=April 7, 2014 |df= }}</ref> The next killer whale captured, [[Moby Doll]], had been harpooned and shot in 1964 and survived for three months when brought back for display to [[Vancouver]], [[British Columbia]].<ref>"A listing of dolphin/whale captures..." at [https://www.pbs.org/wgbh/pages/frontline/shows/whales/etc/cron.html pbs.org]</ref> The third capture for display occurred in June 1965 when William Lechkobit found a 22-foot (6.7m) male orca in his floating salmon net that had drifted close to shore near [[Namu, British Columbia]]. The killer whale was sold for $8,000 to [[Edward "Ted" Griffin|Ted Griffin]], a [[Seattle, Washington|Seattle]] public aquarium owner. Named after his place of capture, [[Namu (orca)|Namu]] was the subject of [[Namu, the Killer Whale|a film]] that changed some people's attitudes toward orcas.<ref>[https://www.pbs.org/wgbh/pages/frontline/shows/whales/etc/summary.html WGBH Frontline: "Edward 'Ted' Griffin, The Life and Adventures of a Man Who Caught Killer Whales"]. Retrieved March 28, 2008</ref>
In October 1965, [[Shamu]], a very young, 14 foot (4.25m), 2000 lb (900 kg) [[Southern Resident Killer Whales|Southern Resident]] orca was captured by [[Edward "Ted" Griffin|Ted Griffin]] off Penn Cove, [[Puget Sound]] to be a companion for the orca Namu at Griffin's Seattle public aquarium.<ref>[http://outsideonline.com/outside/culture/201007/killer-whale-behavior-trainer-death-seaworld.html "The Killer in the Pool", Zimmermann, Tim, ''Outside Magazine'', 2010 July] Retrieved 2010 July 12</ref><ref>[http://www.seattlepi.com/default/article/Granny-s-Struggle-A-black-and-white-gold-rush-is-1216881.php "Granny's Struggle: A black and white gold rush is on", Lyke, M. L., Seattle Post-Intelligencer 2006 October 11] Retrieved 2010 July 12</ref><ref>[https://www.pbs.org/wgbh/pages/frontline/shows/whales/etc/orcas1.html "Stories of Captive Killer Whales," PBS link]</ref> Her name means ‘Friend of Namu’<ref>https://www.orlandovillas.com/florida_guide/how-did-shamu-get-her-name.aspx</ref> (alternately 'She-Namu').<ref>https://www.outsideonline.com/1924946/killer-pool</ref> However, Shamu did not get along with Namu and so was sold to SeaWorld in San Diego in December 1965.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.10news.com/news/13334667/detail.html|title=SeaWorld Investigation: Secrets Below the Surface|publisher=KGTV San Diego|accessdate=July 23, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web | url=http://www.orcaaware.org/shamu.html | title=Shamu - Orca Aware| publisher=Orca Aware}}</ref>
During the 1960s and early 1970s, nearly 50 killer whales were taken from Pacific waters for exhibition. The Southern Resident community of the Northeast Pacific lost 48 of its members to captivity. By 1976, only 80 killer whales were left in the community, which remains endangered. With subsequent captures, the theme parks learned more about avoiding injury during capture and subsequent care of killer whales, and discovered that they could be trained to perform tricks, making them a great attraction to visitors. As commercial demand increased, growing numbers of Pacific orcas were captured, peaking in 1970.<ref name="Heimlich">Heimlich, Sara and Boran, James. ''Killer Whales'' (2001) Voyageur Press, Stillwater, Minnesota.</ref>
A turning point came with a mass capture of orcas from the L-25 pod in August 1970 at Penn Cove, Puget Sound off the coast of [[Washington (U.S. state)|Washington]]. The Penn Cove capture became controversial due to the large number of wild killer whales that were taken (seven) and the number of deaths that resulted: four juveniles died, as well as one adult female who drowned when she became tangled in a net while attempting to reach her calf. In his interview for the [[CNN]] documentary ''[[Blackfish (film)|Blackfish]]'', former diver John Crowe told how all five of the whales had their abdomen slit open and filled with rocks, their tails weighted down with anchors and chains, in an attempt to conceal the deaths.<ref>{{cite web|last=Aguilar|first=Rose|title=Blackfish: Highlighting the plight of captive orcas|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/indepth/opinion/2013/10/blackfish-highlighting-plight-captive-orcas-201310256590532291.html|work=[[Aljazeera]]|publisher=Aljazeera Satellite Network|accessdate=November 5, 2013}}</ref> The facts surrounding their deaths were discovered three months later after three of the dead whales washed ashore on [[Whidbey Island]]. Public concern about the welfare of the animals and the effect of captures on the wild pods led to the [[Marine Mammal Protection Act of 1972|Marine Mammal Protection Act]] being passed in 1972 by the [[United States Congress|US Congress]], protecting orcas from being harassed or killed, and requiring special permits for capture. Since then, few wild orcas have been captured in Northeastern Pacific waters.<ref>[http://www.inkokomo.com/dolphin/orca.html "The Capture of Orcas"] In Kokomo. Retrieved February 14, 2009. {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090402162957/http://www.inkokomo.com/dolphin/orca.html |date=April 2, 2009 }}</ref><ref>[http://seattletimes.nwsource.com/html/snohomishcountynews/2004126831_capture16n0.html "Since first orca capture, views have changed"]. ''[[The Seattle Times]]''. Retrieved February 14, 2009.</ref>
[[Lolita (orca)|Lolita]], originally known as Tokitae, was a survivor of the Penn Cove captures. She was about six years old at time of capture and is now the oldest captive killer whale. Lolita is the subject of the documentary ''Lolita: Slave to Entertainment'', released in 2008.<ref>[http://www.orcanetwork.org/captivity/lolitatoday.html "Lolita's Life Today"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090216034307/http://orcanetwork.org/captivity/lolitatoday.html |date=February 16, 2009 }} Orca Network. Retrieved February 12, 2009.</ref> Various groups still argue that Lolita should be released into the wild.<ref>[http://www.pnwlocalnews.com/sanjuans/jsj/opinion/31014829.html "Orca survival trumps profits, 'ownership' "] ''San Juan Journal''. Retrieved February 14, 2009.</ref><ref>[http://www.seattlepi.com/local/172929_orca12.html "Free Lolita! Bid to bring orca 'home' heats up"] ''[[Seattle Post-Intelligencer]]''. Retrieved February 14, 2009.</ref>
===Icelandic captures=== [[File:Keiko-weighing.jpg|right|thumb|250px|Keiko is weighed as he is loaded into his specially made transport tank at the Oregon State Aquarium, on September 9, 1998.]]
When the US Marine Mammal Protection Act of 1972 effectively stopped the capture of Pacific orcas, exhibitors found an area more tolerant of killer whale captures in [[Iceland]]. Icelandic herring fishermen had traditionally seen killer whales as competitors for their catch, and sale of live killer whales promised a large new source of income. 48 live killer whales captured in Icelandic waters were exported to marine parks between 1976 and 1988. The capture process was based on luring the orcas by dumping leftovers from [[herring]] fishing in front of the pod, capturing the killer whales in a [[purse seine]] net, selecting desirable animals and hauling them on board in a specially designed frame, then placing them in foam-lined boxes full of seawater.<ref>[http://www.orcahome.de/iceland.htm ''The Icelandic live-capture fishery for killer whales 1976–1988''] Orca Home. Retrieved March 7, 2009.</ref> However, restrictions on US killer whale import permits and advances in captive breeding programs meant that the market never became as large as expected. Growing concern from [[conservationists]] and [[animal rights activists]] has caused the Icelandic government to limit the number of orcas that may be captured each year.<ref>[https://www.pbs.org/wgbh/pages/frontline/shows/whales/keiko/world.html "A Whale of a Business"] PBS, Reproduced from "The Performing Orca, Why the Show Must Stop" by [[Erich Hoyt]]. Retrieved February 14, 2009.</ref>
Perhaps the best known of the Icelandic captives is [[Keiko (orca)|Keiko]], caught in 1979 and sold to the Icelandic aquarium in [[Hafnarfjörður]]. Three years later, he was sold to Marineland Canada, where he first started performing for the public and developed skin [[lesion]]s indicative of poor health. He was then sold to [[Reino Aventura]] (now named [[Six Flags Mexico]]), an [[amusement park]] in Mexico City, in 1985. He was the star of the 1993 movie ''[[Free Willy]]'', the publicity from which led to an effort by [[Warner Bros.|Warner Brothers Studio]] to find him a better home. Using donations from the studio, [[Craig McCaw]] the [[Oregon Coast Aquarium]] in [[Newport, Oregon]] spent over $7 million to construct facilities to return him to health with the hope of returning him to the wild. He was airlifted to his new home in January 1996, where he soon regained weight. In September 1998, he was flown to Klettsvik Bay in [[Vestmannaeyjar]] in Iceland, and gradually reintroduced to the wild, returning to the open sea in July 11, 2002. Keiko died from pneumonia in December 12, 2003 at the age of 27 years.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.keiko.com/history.html |title=Keiko's Story: The Timeline |publisher=Keiko.com |date=December 12, 2003 |accessdate=April 29, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.keiko.com/ |title=The Free Willy Keiko Foundation |publisher=Keiko.com |date= |accessdate=April 29, 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140517145357/http://keiko.com/ |archivedate=May 17, 2014 |df=mdy }}</ref> He had become lethargic and had a loss of appetite.
===North Western Pacific captures=== 1,477 killer whales were hunted in Japanese waters between 1948 and 1972, 545 of them around [[Hokkaido]]. Killer whale encounters in Japanese waters are now rare.<ref name=Estes2007>{{Cite book|last=Estes|first=J.A.|year=2007|title=Whales, whaling, and ocean ecosystems|isbn=0-520-24884-8|publisher=University of California Press|location=Berkeley}}</ref> In 1997 a group of ten killer whales was corralled by Japanese fisherman banging on iron rods and using water bombs to disorient the animals and force them into a bay near [[Taiji, Wakayama]], a technique known as [[dolphin drive hunting]] which [[Taiji dolphin drive hunt|these villagers have been practising for years]]. The orcas were held in the bay for two days before being auctioned to Japanese marine parks. Five animals were released, and the other five transported via road or sea to the aquariums. All five are dead.<ref>[http://www.orca-zone.com/news/2007/02-07b-2007.html "More Orcas Under Threat As A Cruel Capture Is Commemorated"] {{webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20120908011417/http://www.orca-zone.com/news/2007/02-07b-2007.html |date=September 8, 2012 }} Orca Zone. Retrieved February 15, 2009.</ref>
The first live killer whale captured in [[Russia]] was an {{convert|18|ft|m|adj=on}}-long female estimated to be about six years old, captured off the Pacific coast of the [[Kamchatka]] district on September 26, 2003. She was transferred over {{convert|7000|mi|km}} to a facility owned by the Utrish Dolphinarium on the [[Black Sea]], where she died in October 2003 after less than a month in captivity.<ref>[http://www.hsus.org/hsi/oceans/marine_mammals_in_captivity/kamchatka_orca_first_victim_of_russias_captive_orca_business.html "Kamchatka Orca First Victim of Russia's Captive Orca Business"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081227103611/http://www.hsus.org/hsi/oceans/marine_mammals_in_captivity/kamchatka_orca_first_victim_of_russias_captive_orca_business.html |date=December 27, 2008 }} Humane Society International. Retrieved February 15, 2009.</ref>
===Killer whales born in captivity=== The majority of today's theme-park killer whales were [[captive breeding|born in captivity]]: 33 out of 56. [[Kalina (whale)|Kalina]], a female orca born in September 1985 at SeaWorld Orlando, was the first captive orca calf to survive more than two months. Kalina's mother is an Icelandic female named [[Katina (whale)|Katina]], and her father, [[Ramu III (Winston)|Winston]] (also known as Ramu III), was a Pacific Southern Resident, making Kalina an Atlantic/Pacific hybrid – a unique situation that would not have occurred in the wild.<ref name="Kalina">[http://www.orca-spirit.co.uk/1210.html?*session*id*key*=*session*id*val* "Kalina"] Orca Spirit. Retrieved February 15, 2009.</ref>
The first killer whale conceived through [[artificial insemination#in animals|artificial insemination]] was Nakai, who was born to [[Kasatka]] at the [[SeaWorld]] park in San Diego in September 2001.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/sci/tech/1523214.stm "Artificially inseminated killer whale gives birth"] BBC. Retrieved February 14, 2009.</ref> A female killer whale named [[Kohana (orca)|Kohana]], the second killer whale conceived in this manner, was born at the same park eight months later.<ref>Surprisingly, Kasatka is Kohana's grandmother.[https://archive.is/20120723050303/http://www.btinternet.com/%7Efriendoftheorcas/sherie_new/Kohana_page.htm "Kohana"] Friend of the Orcas. Retrieved February 12, 2009.</ref> Artificial insemination lets park owners maintain a healthier genetic mix in the small groups of killer whales at each park while avoiding the stress of moving the animals between marinas.<ref>[http://nationalzoo.si.edu/ConservationAndScience/SpotlightOnScience/monfortorca20040618.cfm "Artificial Insemination Produces Killer Whales"] Smithsonian National Zoological Park. Retrieved February 14, 2009. {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090204120553/http://nationalzoo.si.edu/ConservationAndScience/SpotlightOnScience/monfortorca20040618.cfm |date=February 4, 2009 }}</ref>
The practice of exhibiting killer whales born in captivity is less controversial than of retaining free-born orcas, since the captive-born orcas have known no other world and may not be able to adapt to life in the wild. Captive breeding also promises to reduce incentives to capture wild orcas.<ref name=Davis1996>{{Cite book|last=Davis|first=Susan G.|year=1996|title=Spectacular nature : corporate culture and the Sea World experience (p72ff)|isbn=978-0-520-20981-7|publisher=University of California Press|location=Berkeley}}</ref> However, in January 2002 the Miami Seaquarium stated that captive orcas are dying faster than they are being born, and as it is virtually impossible to obtain orcas captured from the wild, the business of exhibiting captive orcas may eventually disappear.<ref>[http://www.orcanetwork.org/captivity/updat6.html ''Free Lolita Update #52 – ACT NOW to help Lolita''] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090311061911/http://orcanetwork.org/captivity/updat6.html |date=March 11, 2009 }} Orca Network. Retrieved March 7, 2009.</ref>
==Captivity locations== [[File:Orcas at SeaWorld show.jpg|thumb|right|250px|Corky II, a female orca performing at SeaWorld, San Diego, California]] As of September 29, 2016, orcas in 13 facilities in North and South America, Europe and Asia provide entertainment for theme park visitors.<ref>http://www.orcahome.de/orcatank.htm
http://www.bbc.com/earth/story/20160310-why-killer-whales-should-not-be-kept-in-captivity </ref> Building the physical infrastructure of the parks requires major capital expenditure, but as the star attractions the orcas are arguably the most valuable and irreplaceable assets.
===SeaWorld=== {{Main|SeaWorld}} SeaWorld is a chain of [[marine mammal park]]s in the [[United States]] and is the largest owner of captive killer whales in the world. The parks feature killer whale, [[sea lion]], and [[dolphin]] shows and zoological displays featuring various other marine animals. The parks' icon is Shamu, the orca.<ref>[http://www.aquaticabyseaworld.com/downloads/presskit.pdf SeaWorld Press Release Kit] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070307105637/http://www.aquaticabyseaworld.com/downloads/presskit.pdf |date=March 7, 2007 }}. Retrieved March 5, 2007.</ref> Parks include: *[[SeaWorld San Diego]], [[San Diego, California]]; home of Corky II, Orkid, Ulises, Nakai, Kalia, Ikaika, Keet, Shouka, Makani, and Amaya *[[SeaWorld Orlando]], [[Orlando, Florida]]; home of Katina, Trua, Nalani, Kayla, Malia, and Makaio *[[SeaWorld San Antonio]], [[San Antonio, Texas]]; home of Kyuquot, Tuar, Takara, Sakari, and Kamea
There was also a fourth park named [[SeaWorld Ohio]], but the park closed in 2001.
[[File:Miamiseaquariumlolita.jpg|thumb|right|250px|The killer whale show at the '''Miami Seaquarium''' starring Lolita.]]
===Miami Seaquarium=== {{Main|Miami Seaquarium}} The Miami Seaquarium is an aquarium located on [[Virginia Key]] in [[Biscayne Bay]] near downtown [[Miami, Florida]]. A subsidiary of the privately held [[Wometco Enterprises]], the Seaquarium was the first major marine park attraction in South Florida, opening in 1955. In addition to marine mammals, the Miami Seaquarium houses fish, sharks, sea turtles, birds and reptiles.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.miamiseaquarium.com/visitor_info/history.asp |title=History of the Miami Seaquarium |accessdate=November 30, 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071016061310/http://miamiseaquarium.com/visitor_info/history.asp |archivedate=October 16, 2007 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> It is home to [[Lolita (orca)|Lolita]] (aka Tokitae), the oldest killer whale in captivity.<ref>[http://www.orcanetwork.org/captivity/lolitatoday.html Lolita's Life Today] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090216034307/http://orcanetwork.org/captivity/lolitatoday.html |date=February 16, 2009 }}. Retrieved June 6, 2010.</ref>
===Marineland Canada=== {{Main|Marineland (Ontario)}} Marineland is a privately held themed amusement and animal exhibition park in the city of [[Niagara Falls, Ontario]], [[Canada]]. Owing to its proximity to the falls and other natural park areas and its blend of animal attractions and rides, it is one of the main tourist destinations in Niagara Falls, in Ontario, Canada.<ref>[http://www.marinelandcanada.com/ "Marineland Canada website"] Marineland Canada. Retrieved February 15, 2009.</ref> It currently only holds Kiska.
In 2015, the House of Commons passed Bill S-203, Ending the Captivity of Whales and Dolphins Act, and sent it to the [[Senate of Canada]]. Marineland would be one of two facilities in Canada to be affected by the law after the bill is passed. No other captive orcas were held in Canada, but the [[Vancouver Aquarium]] had dolphins. In 2018, Progressive Conservatives in the Senate, led by Sen. Don Plett, were accused of using procedural obstruction to keep the bill from moving to a vote. In June 2018, such senators added amendments intended to exclude Marineland and the Vancouver Aquarium from being covered by the bill. After three years, the eventual outcome was not yet known in October 2018.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.thestar.com/ipolitics/federal/2018/10/04/bill-to-ban-whale-and-dolphin-captivity-is-being-stalled-in-the-senate-again.html|title=Bill to ban whale and dolphin captivity is being stalled in the Senate — again|first=Holly|last=Lake|date=May 4, 2017|publisher=Toronto Star}}</ref>
===Marineland (Antibes)=== {{Main|Marineland (Antibes)}} Marineland is an animal exhibition park in [[Antibes]], [[France]], founded in 1970. It receives more than 1,200,000 visitors per year, and is the only French sea park featuring two cetacean species: killer whales and [[dolphins]]. The park is a subsidiary of [[Parques Reunidos]], a Spanish group with properties in Europe, Argentina and the US. It currently holds Inouk (M), Wikie (F), Moana (M), and Keijo (M) and owns Shouka (F), who is at SeaWorld San Diego.
===Loro Parque=== {{Main|Loro Parque}} Loro Parque ([[Spanish language|Spanish]] for "[[parrot]] park") is a [[zoo]] located on the outskirts of [[Puerto de la Cruz, Santa Cruz de Tenerife|Puerto de la Cruz]] on [[Tenerife]]. The park has the world's largest indoor [[penguin]] exhibition, the longest [[shark]] tunnel in Europe, and is one of only two parks in Europe to house killer whales.<ref>[http://www.loroparque.com/ingles/fullpage.html "Loro Parque Website"] Loro Parque. Retrieved February 16, 2009. {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090226023332/http://www.loroparque.com/ingles/fullpage.html |date=February 26, 2009 }}</ref>
In February 2006, Loro Parque received four young killer whales; two males, Keto (born in 1995) and Tekoa (born in 2000), and two females, Kohana (2002) and Skyla (2004) on loan from SeaWorld. Sea World has sent its own professionals, including trainers, curators & veterinarians, to supplement the staff at Loro Parque. In 2004 and 2005, before the killer whales were brought to Loro Parque, eight animal trainers from the park were sent to Sea World parks in Texas and Florida for training. However, only half of these trainers are currently employed in Orca Ocean, Loro Parque's facility for the killer whales. None of the subsequent employees hired have been sent to Sea World parks for training.<ref>{{cite web|author=M. Á. Montero / Puerto De La Cruz |url=http://www.abc.es/20101018/comunidad-canarias/adiestradores-loro-parque-tienen-20101018.html |title=Los adiestradores del Loro Parque no tienen titulación oficial |publisher=ABC.es |date=October 18, 2010 |accessdate=April 29, 2014}}</ref> On December 24, 2009, orca trainer Alexis Martinez, age 29, was killed during a Christmas show rehearsal when he was attacked by one of the killer whales, presumably [[Keto (killer whale)|Keto]], resulting in his drowning. He had worked at Loro Parque since 2004. From this date the trainers no longer enter the water with the orcas during live shows. In December of 2017, SeaWorld announced that the orcas they loaned to Loro Parque now belonged to the Spanish amusement park.
===Mundo Marino=== {{Main|Mundo Marino}} Mundo Marino, located south of [[Buenos Aires]] in the coastal town of San Clemente del Tuyú, Argentina, is the largest aquarium in South America. Mundo Marino is home to one male killer whale, Kshamenk, that was stranded, or force-stranded, in 1992.<ref>{{cite web|last=Humane Society|title=Held Captive: Orcas|url=http://www.humanesociety.org/issues/captive_marine/facts/captive_orcas.html|accessdate=July 25, 2012}}</ref> Kshamenk is estimated to have been around 4 1/2 years old when captured.
===Other marine exhibitions=== *Kamogawa SeaWorld, [[Kamogawa, Chiba]], Japan; home of Lovey, Lara, Earth, and Luna *[[Port of Nagoya Public Aquarium]], [[Nagoya]], Aichi, Japan; home of Ran II, Stella, and Lynn *Moskvarium, [[Moscow]], Russia; home of Narnia, Nord, and Juliet *TINRO Center, Vladivostok, Russia; home of three-four unnamed orcas, one male and two females *Chimelong Ocean Kingdom, Henqin, Zhuhai, China; home of four unnamed orcas, two of which are male, the other two are unknown genders *It is unknown where TIN-OO-C1306 currently resides, he/she may be with Chimelong Ocean Kingdom, the TINRO Center, or at another park.
==Captivity conditions==
===Tank size and water conditions=== Legal requirements for tank size vary greatly from country to country. In the US, the minimum enclosure size is set by the [[Code of Federal Regulations]], {{CodeFedReg |9|3|104}}, under the ''Specifications for the Humane Handling, Care, Treatment, and Transportation of Marine Mammals''.<ref>[http://www.ecfr.gov/cgi-bin/text-idx?SID=c7a201bd3f7d31d5f8218167efcd49ba&node=9:1.0.1.1.3.5.31.5&rgn=div8 ''Title 9 CFR Part 3, Subpart E''] Retrieved March 10, 2014</ref> In 9 CFR 3.104, Table III classifies killer whales as Group I [[cetacea]]ns with an average length of {{convert|24|ft}}. Based on length, Table I states up to two killer whales may be held in a pool with a minimum horizontal dimension (the diameter of a circular pool of water) of twice that length or {{convert|48|ft}} and a minimum depth of {{convert|12|ft}}, giving a minimum volume of {{convert|615|m3|ft3|order=flip}} for two killer whales. Each additional killer whale requires a pool with an additional {{convert|308|m3|ft3|order=flip}} of volume. 9 CFR 3.104 also requires a minimum of {{convert|63|m2|ft2|order=flip}} surface area per killer whale in Table IV (the example with a cylindrical tank {{convert|48|ft}} in diameter for two whales provides {{convert|905|ft2|m2}} of surface area per killer whale). [[Swiss]] regulations require a larger minimum volume: {{convert|400|m2}} × {{convert|4|m}} deep for two killer whales, or {{convert|1600|m3}}. The Alliance of Marine Mammal Parks and Aquariums (AMMPA) goes further, and recommends {{convert|1918|m3}} for two killer whales.<ref>[http://www.waza.org/virtualzoo/factsheet.php?id=111-002-004-001&view=Marine%20Mammals ''Killer whale''] World Association of Zoos and Aquariums. Retrieved March 7, 2009.</ref> The US exhibitors of captive killer whales belong to the AMMPA, but exhibitors in other countries do not.<ref>[http://www.ammpa.org/ourmembers.html ''Our Members''] Alliance of Marine Mammal Parks and Aquariums. Retrieved March 7, 2009.</ref>
The tanks in most marine parks are considerably larger than the minimum sizes required by regulations. However, the Miami Seaquarium has been criticized for the small size of the tank holding their sole killer whale, Lolita, which is less than two of her body lengths wide at any point. Building a new tank would be costly and there is little prospect of replacing the aging Lolita.<ref>[http://www.miaminewtimes.com/2008-08-21/news/seaquarium-activists-push-to-free-lolita-the-whale ''Seaquarium Activists Push to Free Lolita the Whale''] Village Voice Media. Retrieved March 7, 2009.</ref>
===Nutrition and medical care=== On average, an adult killer whale in the wild may eat about three to four percent of their body weight daily,<ref>[http://library.thinkquest.org/TQ0311684/orcadietandlocation.html ''Orca diet and location''] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090307063412/http://library.thinkquest.org/TQ0311684/orcadietandlocation.html |date=March 7, 2009 }} Oracle ThinkQuest. Retrieved March 8, 2009</ref> or as much as 227 kg (500 lb) of food for a six-ton male. Their diet in the wild depends on what is available, and may include fish, walruses, seals, sea lions, penguins, squid, sea turtles, sharks and whales.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://kids.nationalgeographic.com/Animals/CreatureFeature/Orca|title=National Geographic creature feature|author=Hughes, Catherine D.|accessdate=March 8, 2009}}</ref> According to SeaWorld, each of their adult orcas receives 140 to 240 pounds of food per day, primarily herring, capelin, salmon and mackerel. To maintain their alertness, the killer whales are fed at sporadic intervals throughout the day (as would happen in the wild) and feeding is often combined with training and shows. Each batch of fish is carefully tested to determine its nutritive composition, and each killer whale's weight, activity and health is carefully monitored to determine any special dietary requirements.<ref>[http://www.seaworld.org/ask-shamu/faq.htm#sw-animals ''Ask Shamu''] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131003114525/http://www.seaworld.org/ask-shamu/faq.htm#sw-animals#sw-animals |date=October 3, 2013 }} SeaWorld. Retrieved March 8, 2009.</ref>
Killer whales have been the subject of extensive medical research since their first capture, and much is known about prevention and treatment of the common [[virus|viral]] and [[bacterial]] infections, including [[vaccination]] and use of [[antibiotics]] and other medicines.<ref name=Dierauf2001>{{Cite book|last=Dierauf|first=Edited by Leslie A Gulland D Frances M|year=2001|title=CRC handbook of marine mammal medicine|isbn = 0-8493-0839-9|publisher=CRC Press|location=Boca Raton, FL}}</ref> [[Allometric]] principles and therapeutic drug monitoring are used to accurately determine the doses and avoid toxicity.<ref>[http://www.bioone.org/doi/abs/10.1638/03-078 ''Comparison Of Amikacin Pharmacokintetics In A Killer Whale (Orcinus Orca) And A Beluga Whale (Delphinapterus Leucas)''] American Association of Zoo Veterinarians. Retrieved March 8, 2009.</ref>
===Training=== Whales are trained using a system of reward (called "[[positive reinforcement]]" by trainers) by giving the killer whale food or other reinforcement when they are successful, and withholding it when they are not.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.pbs.org/wgbh/pages/frontline/shows/whales/debate/trainers.html |title=The Debate – Dangers To Trainers | A Whale Of A Business | FRONTLINE |publisher=PBS |date= |accessdate=April 29, 2014}}</ref> Secondary reinforcement—things not essential to life, such as play time, tactile rewards and fun games—can also be used as rewards.<ref name=Resnick1994>{{Cite book|last=Resnick|first=Jane|year=1994|title=All about training Shamu|isbn=1-884506-11-9|publisher=Third Story Books|location=Bridgeport, Conn.}}</ref>
==Issues with captivity== The practice of keeping killer whales in captivity is controversial, and organizations such as [[World Animal Protection]] and the [[Whale and Dolphin Conservation]] campaign against the captivity of killer whales. Orcas in captivity may develop physical pathologies, such as the [[dorsal fin]] collapse seen in 80–90% of captive males. {{cn|date=October 2018}}
The captive environment bears little resemblance to their wild habitat, and the social groups that the killer whales are put into are foreign to those found in the wild.<ref name="Orcas in captivity">{{cite web|url=http://www.wdcs.org/dan/publishing.nsf/allweb/A141A8A02A2FE3C7802568F60029D1F9 |title=Orcas in captivity |publisher=Whale and Dolphin Conservation Society |accessdate=July 25, 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070805220554/http://www.wdcs.org/dan/publishing.nsf/allweb/A141A8A02A2FE3C7802568F60029D1F9 |archivedate=August 5, 2007 }}</ref> Critics claim that captive life is stressful due to small tanks, false social groupings and chemically altered water. Captive killer whales have been observed acting aggressively toward themselves, other killer whales, or humans, which critics say is a result of [[Stress (medicine)|stress]].{{citation needed|date=November 2015}}
===Disease and lifespan=== The lifespan of killer whales in captivity versus wild killer whales is disputed. Several studies published in scientific journals show that the average mortality rate for captive killer whales is approximately three times higher than in the wild.<ref name="ECM2013">{{cite book|author=Parsons, ECM|title=An Introduction to Marine Mammal Biology and Conservation|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=XbyxI-d5idcC&pg=PA170|year=2013|publisher=Jones & Bartlett Publishers|isbn=978-0-7637-8344-0|page=170}}</ref> A 2015 study in the ''[[Journal of Mammalogy]]'', authored by SeaWorld's vice-president of theriogenology, Todd Robeck,<ref name=":1">{{Cite journal|last=Robeck|first=Todd R.|last2=Willis|first2=Kevin|last3=Scarpuzzi|first3=Michael R.|last4=O’Brien|first4=Justine K.|date=2015-07-10|title=Comparisons of life-history parameters between free-ranging and captive killer whale (Orcinus orca) populations for application toward species management|url=http://jmammal.oxfordjournals.org/content/early/2015/07/09/jmammal.gyv113|journal=Journal of Mammalogy|language=en|pages=gyv113|doi=10.1093/jmammal/gyv113|issn=0022-2372|pmc=4668992|pmid=26937049|volume=96}}</ref><ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.co.uk/entry/seaworld-tilikum-orca-announcement-uses-misleading-statistics-on-life-expectancy_uk_56e2c472e4b096ed3adbcfc3|title=The Real Story Behind SeaWorld's 'Clearly Wrong' Statement On Its Dying Orca|website=The Huffington Post|language=en-GB|access-date=2016-03-12}}</ref> concluded that the life expectancy for killer whales born at SeaWorld is the same as those in the wild.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Green|first1=Amy|title=Study Concludes Life Expectancy of SeaWorld Orcas Same As In The Wild|url=http://www.wmfe.org/study-concludes-life-expectancy-of-seaworld-orcas-same-as-in-the-wild/51238|accessdate=23 July 2015|agency=WMFE}}</ref> In the wild, female killer whales have a typical lifespan of 60–80 years, and a maximum recorded lifespan of 103 years.<ref>{{cite web|title=World's oldest orca spotted near Vancouver Island|url=http://metronews.ca/news/victoria/1032108/worlds-oldest-orca-whale-spotted-near-vancouver-island/}}</ref> The average lifespan for males in the wild is 30 years, but some live up to 50–60 years.<ref name=nmfssd>{{cite web|title=Killer Whale (Orcinus Orca)|url=http://www.nmfs.noaa.gov/pr/species/mammals/cetaceans/killerwhale.htm#description|accessdate=September 12, 2013}}</ref> The 2015 study has been criticised by Trevor Willis, senior lecturer in marine biology at the University of Portsmouth, who stated that the study is misleading, "clearly wrong" and indicative of "poor practice". He stated that it is misleading in two ways: "First, it compares two completely different circumstances: the controlled environment of a swimming pool, with highly trained vets on hand; and the wild ocean. "There are no predators in a swimming pool. Second, and in the absence of any other information, it appears they’ve looked at the survival rate of calves in the first two years of life and extrapolated it out 50 years into the future." He also stated that no captive orca has lived for 55.8 years,<ref name=":1" /> the recorded average life expectancy of adult orcas at SeaWorld.<ref name=":0" />
SeaWorld San Antonio's 14-year-old [[Taku (whale)|Taku]], born in captivity, died suddenly on October 17, 2007. Trainers were notified that Taku had been acting differently a week before his death. The [[necropsy]] determined that Taku had died from a sudden case of [[pneumonia]], a common illness among captive orcas.<ref name="woai">{{cite web|url=http://www.woai.com/mostpopular/story.aspx?content_id=e9fdad0c-5dcf-407a-a1b7-48c953e7ef2a |title=Sea World Killer Whale Dies |accessdate=October 18, 2007 |date= |work= |publisher=[[WOAI-TV]] |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071030020619/http://www.woai.com/mostpopular/story.aspx?content_id=e9fdad0c-5dcf-407a-a1b7-48c953e7ef2a |archivedate=October 30, 2007 |deadurl=yes |df=mdy }}</ref><ref name="dmn">{{cite web|url=http://www.dallasnews.com/sharedcontent/APStories/stories/D8SCDTOO0.html |title=Killer whale at SeaWorld San Antonio dies |accessdate=October 19, 2007 |date= |work=[[Dallas Morning News]] |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071023181222/http://www.dallasnews.com/sharedcontent/APStories/stories/D8SCDTOO0.html |archivedate=October 23, 2007 |deadurl=yes |df=mdy }}</ref> It was also discovered that Taku was infected by the West nile virus, transmitted by mosquitos.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.scribd.com/doc/68892225/A-Second-Captive-Orca-Taku-Dies-from-Virus-Transmitted-By-Mosquito-Vector |title=A Second Captive Orca, Taku, Dies from Virus Transmitted By Mosquito Vector |doi=10.1578/AM.35.2.2009.163 |publisher=Scribd.com |date=October 15, 2011 |accessdate=April 29, 2014}}</ref>
The shallowness of orca tanks forces orcas to spend a lot of time at the surface. So much time at the surface leads to prolonged exposure to [[ultraviolet]] (UV) rays. Prolonged exposure to the surface and UV rays is attributed to sunburns and the development of cataracts in orcas in captivity. Orcas in the wild would live at higher latitudes, meaning less intense sun, and spend more time in deeper, darker waters.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://theorcaproject.wordpress.com/2011/01/20/keto-tilikum-express-stress-of-orca-captivity/ |date=2011 |accessdate=October 6, 2015|title=Keto and Tilikum Express the Stress of Orca Captivity}}</ref> While it is uncertain the effects of prolonged UV exposure to orcas' skin, since captive orca necropsies are extremely secretive,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hsi.org/assets/pdfs/orca_white_paper.pdf |date=2011 |accessdate=October 6, 2015|title=Killer Controversy: Why Orcas Should No Longer Be Kept in Captivity}}</ref> it seems logical that prolonged exposure to UV rays on unprotected skin would have the same negative effects such as [[melanoma]] (skin cancer) on orcas as it does on humans.
The original Namu developed a bacterial infection which damaged his nervous system, causing him to become nonresponsive to people. During his illness he charged full-speed into the wire mesh of his pen, thrashed violently for a few minutes and then died.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rockisland.com/~orcasurv/changing.htm |title=The First Captive Killer Whales – A Changing Attitude |publisher=Rockisland.com |date= |accessdate=April 29, 2014}}</ref>
===Dorsal fin collapse=== [[File:Orca collapsed dorsal fin.jpg|thumb|right|300px|This male ([[Tilikum (orca)|Tilikum]]), at [[SeaWorld Orlando]], had a collapsed dorsal fin.]] Most captive male killer whales, and some females, have a [[dorsal fin]] that is partially or completely collapsed to one side. Several hypotheses exist as to why this happens. A dorsal fin is held erect by [[collagen]], which normally hardens in late adolescence.
Scientists from the [[National Marine Fisheries Service]] (NMFS) have reported that "the collapsed dorsal fins commonly seen in captive killer whales do not result from a pathogenic condition, but are instead thought to most likely originate from an irreversible structural change in the fin's collagen over time. Possible explanations for this include: (1) alterations in water balance caused by the stresses of captivity dietary changes, (2) lowered [[blood pressure]] due to reduced activity patterns, or (3) overheating of the collagen brought on by greater exposure of the fin to the ambient air."<ref name=ConservationPlan/> According to SeaWorld's website, another reason for the fin to bend may be the greater amount of time that captive whales spend at the surface, where the fin is not supported by water pressure.<ref name=askshamu>{{cite web|url=http://www.seaworld.org/ask-shamu/faq.htm#sw-animals|title=Ask Shamu: Frequently Asked Questions|publisher=SeaWorld/Busch Gardens|accessdate=May 5, 2008|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131003114525/http://www.seaworld.org/ask-shamu/faq.htm#sw-animals#sw-animals|archive-date=October 3, 2013|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}}</ref> The [[Whale and Dolphin Conservation]] says that dorsal fin collapse is largely explained by captive killer whales swimming in small circles due to the inadequate space in which they have to swim.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wdcs.org/submissions_bin/orcareport.pdf|title=Captive Orcas 'Dying to Entertain You'|last=Williams|first=Vanessa|date=April 30, 2001|publisher=Whale and Dolphin Conservation Society|accessdate=May 5, 2008|format=PDF}}</ref> SeaWorld, however, claims that "Neither the shape nor the droop of a whale's dorsal fin are indicators of a killer whale's health or well-being."<ref name=askshamu/>
Collapsed or collapsing dorsal fins are rare in most wild populations and usually result from a serious injury to the fin, such as from being shot or colliding with a vessel.<ref name=ConservationPlan>{{cite web|url=http://www.nwr.noaa.gov/Marine-Mammals/Whales-Dolphins-Porpoise/Killer-Whales/Conservation-Planning/upload/SRKW-propConsPlan.pdf |title=Proposed Conservation Plan for Southern Resident Killer Whales (Orcinus orca) |date=August 2005 |accessdate=May 7, 2007 |author=National Marine Fisheries Service Northwest Regional Office |format=PDF |work= |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070221111451/http://www.nwr.noaa.gov/Marine-Mammals/Whales-Dolphins-Porpoise/Killer-Whales/Conservation-Planning/upload/SRKW-propConsPlan.pdf |archivedate=February 21, 2007 |deadurl=yes |df=mdy }}</ref> After the 1989 [[Exxon Valdez oil spill|''Exxon Valdez'' oil spill]], the dorsal fins of two male resident killer whales who had been exposed to the oil collapsed, and the animals subsequently died. In 2002, the dorsal fin of a [[beached whale|stranded]] killer whale showed signs of collapse after three days but regained its natural upright appearance as soon as the orca resumed strong normal swimming upon release.<ref name=ConservationPlan/>
It has been reported that seven out of the 30 (23%) wild adult male killer whales from New Zealand waters have bent dorsal fins,<ref name=visser/><ref name=askshamu/><ref>"A recent survey of killer whales off the coast of New Zealand documented that 23% of males had bent dorsal fins."{{cite web|url=http://www.seaworld.org/animal-info/Animal-bytes/animalia/eumetazoa/coelomates/deuterostomes/chordata/craniata/mammalia/cetacea/killer-whale.htm|title=Animal Bytes: Killer Whale|publisher=SeaWorld/Busch Gardens|accessdate=May 8, 2008}}</ref> though this figure includes a variety of dorsal fin abnormalities, including rippled or twisted fins, in addition to simple one-sided collapse.<ref name=visser/> The New Zealand study noted that, in addition to the high prevalence of dorsal fin deformities, two of the 30 adult males in this population also had prolific body scarring that was consistent with bite marks from other killer whales.<ref name=visser/> The prevalence of dorsal fin deformities is 4.7% among adult male orcas in British Columbia and 0.57% in Norway.<ref name=visser>{{cite web|url=http://www.orcaresearch.org/pdf/bodyscars.pdf |title=Prolific body scars and collapsing dorsal fins on killer whales (Orcinus orca) in New Zealand waters |accessdate=March 28, 2008 |author=Ingrid N. Visser |authorlink=Ingrid Visser (researcher) |format=PDF |work= |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080227181900/http://www.orcaresearch.org/pdf/bodyscars.pdf |archivedate=February 27, 2008 |deadurl=yes |df=mdy }}</ref> Amongst the well-studied wild killer whales off the coast of British Columbia, the total rate of dorsal fin collapse is around 1%.<ref name=Hoyt>{{cite web|author=Hoyt, Erich|url=http://www.orcanetwork.org/nathist/biennial.pdf|title=Observations of Disparity between Educational Material Related to Killer Whales (Orcinus Orca) Disseminated by Public Display Institutions and the Scientific Literature|format=PDF|display-authors=etal}}</ref><ref>[http://www.wdcs.org/dan/publishing.nsf/allweb/E65D8438C56B6DD2802568F1002F2DC1 Captive Orcas dying to entertain you] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080204111846/http://www.wdcs.org/dan/publishing.nsf/allweb/E65D8438C56B6DD2802568F1002F2DC1 |date=February 4, 2008 }}</ref>
===Attacks on humans=== {{Main|Orca attacks on humans}} [[ABC News]] reported that captive killer whales have attacked nearly two dozen people since the 1970s.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://abcnews.com/GMA/story?id=2690153|title=ABC News: Killer Whale Attacks SeaWorld Trainer|publisher=ABC News}}</ref> Studies of [[Killer whale#Types|killer whales]] in the wild have identified at least two categories, based on their territorial range. Those living in a limited area, such as Puget Sound or the Strait of Juan de Fuca, are termed "resident" whales, while "transient" whales roam the oceans at will. These "transient" types have to be more aggressive, in order to assert themselves in a wide range of territories and to prey on a variety of different species. This increased aggressiveness does not disappear in captivity.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.time.com/time/health/article/0,8599,1968249,00.html |title=Killer-Whale Tragedy: What Made Tilikum Snap? |date=February 26, 2010 |work=Time Magazine |publisher= |accessdate=March 5, 2010 | first=Jeffrey | last=Kluger}}</ref> Furthermore, captivity itself has been asserted to aggravate aggressive behavior, resulting in a "cetacean equivalent of anxiety disorder."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://cosmiclog.msnbc.msn.com/archive/2010/02/25/2212623.aspx |title=Inside the mind of a 'killer whale' |date=February 25, 2010 |work=Cosmic Log (website) |publisher=MSNBC |accessdate=March 9, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100301075958/http://cosmiclog.msnbc.msn.com/archive/2010/02/25/2212623.aspx |archivedate=March 1, 2010 }}</ref>
Captive killer whale attacks on humans seem to fall mostly into the categories of: biting during feeding, ramming in the water, and holding under water. Killer whales biting trainers during feeding or shows is generally the mildest form of attack seen, but can escalate to an animal dragging the trainer underwater and holding them there until they lose consciousness or drown. Trainers who have had killer whales ram into them in the water tend to suffer from a range of injuries including internal bleeding, broken bones, ruptured organs, and heart attack.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.keepwhaleswild.org/trainer-incidents.php |title=Keep Whales Wild: Trainer Incidents |accessdate=November 5, 2010}}</ref>
[[Tilikum (orca)|Tilikum]], a male killer whale, has been involved in the death of three individuals since his capture near Iceland in November 1983. In 1991, Tilikum and two other killer whales grabbed 20-year-old trainer Keltie Byrne in their mouths and tossed her to each other, drowning Byrne.<ref>[http://www.orca-spirit.co.uk/1210.html?*session*id*key*=*session*id*val* "Tilikum"] Orca Spirit. Retrieved February 12, 2009.</ref><ref>http://theorcaproject.files.wordpress.com/2011/02/keltie-byrne-coroner-inquest-5pg.pdf</ref> On July 5, 1999, Daniel P. Dukes visited SeaWorld and stayed after the park closed, evading security so as to enter a killer whale tank.<ref>[https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9D0DE6DA1E3CF932A1575AC0A96F958260 ''https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9D0DE6DA1E3CF932A1575AC0A96F958260''] New York Times September 21, 1999. Retrieved March 7, 2009.</ref> He was found dead the next day, floating in Tilikum's pool. He died due to a combination of [[hypothermia]]{{dubious|date=April 2016}}, trauma, and [[drowning]] but Dukes was covered in bruises, abrasions and bite marks, and his scrotum had been ripped open,<ref>{{cite web|title=Daniel Dukes Medical Examiners Report|url=https://www.scribd.com/doc/119465495/Daniel-Dukes-Medical-Examiners-Report|accessdate=August 8, 2013|quote=Postmortem abrasions, laceration and avulsion of the scrotum with testes. Avulsion of the skin of the pubic area including the scrotal sac and testis, with the left testis separate.}}</ref> indicating that Tilikum had toyed with the victim. It is unclear whether Tilikum actually caused the man's death.<ref>[http://www.clickorlando.com/news/22659901/detail.html OSHA Investigates Trainer's Death, Separate Incident – Orlando News Story – WKMG Orlando] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111023032047/http://www.clickorlando.com/news/22659901/detail.html |date=October 23, 2011 }}</ref> On February 24, 2010, after a noontime performance at Sea World, Orlando, Florida, Tilikum killed trainer Dawn Brancheau during a training session with the whale.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2010/US/02/24/killer.whale.trainer.death/index.html|work=CNN|title=SeaWorld trainer killed by killer whale - CNN.com|accessdate=April 28, 2010|date=February 25, 2010}} See also: [[Tilikum (orca)|Tilikum]]</ref> This latest incident with Tilikum reawakened a heated discussion about the effect of captivity on the killer whale's behavior.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.orcanetwork.org/news/tillikumnewsrelease.html |title=What's best for "Tilikum" now, and what have we learned? |publisher=Orcanetwork.org |date=February 24, 2010 |accessdate=April 29, 2014}}</ref> In May 2012, [[Occupational Safety and Health Administration]] administrative law judge Ken Welsch faulted SeaWorld for the death of Dawn Brancheau and introduced regulations requiring a physical barrier between trainers and killer whales.<ref>{{cite web|title=Secretary of Labor, Complainant v. SeaWorld of Florida – Decision and Order|url=http://www.oshrc.gov/foia/SecLabSeaWorld/Sea-World_ALJ.pdf|accessdate=June 13, 2012|archivedate=June 8, 2012|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120608211034/http://www.oshrc.gov/foia/SecLabSeaWorld/Sea-World_ALJ.pdf}}</ref>
[[Kasatka]], a female killer whale who was captured off the coast of Iceland in October 1978 at the age of one year, has shown aggression toward humans. Kasatka tried to bite a trainer during a show in 1993, and again in 1999.<ref name="signonsandiego">{{cite web|url=http://www.signonsandiego.com/news/metro/20061130-9999-7m30shamu.html |title=Killer whale bites trainer, takes him to tank bottom |author=Repard, Pauline |date=November 30, 2006 |publisher=''[[SignOnSanDiego.com]]'' |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090501164501/http://www.signonsandiego.com/news/metro/20061130-9999-7m30shamu.html |archivedate=May 1, 2009 |df= }}</ref> On November 30, 2006, Kasatka grabbed a trainer and dragged him underwater during their show. The trainer suffered puncture wounds to both feet and a torn metatarsal ligament in his left foot.<ref>[http://www.huffingtonpost.com/david-kirby/near-death-at-seaworld-wo_b_1697243.html "Near Death At SeaWorld: Worldwide Exclusive Video"] Huffington Post July 24, 2012.</ref><ref>[http://www.cnn.com/2006/US/11/29/killer.whale/index.html "Killer whale attacks Sea World trainer"] CNN November 30, 2006.</ref><ref>[http://www.freewebs.com/beyondtheblue/kasatka.htm "Kasatka"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090519013825/http://www.freewebs.com/beyondtheblue/kasatka.htm |date=May 19, 2009 }} Beyond the Blue. Retrieved February 14, 2009.</ref>
On Christmas Eve of 2009, 29-year-old [[Death of Alexis Martínez|Alexis Martínez]] of Loro Parque, [[Tenerife]], Spain was killed by a whale named Keto. After spending two and a half minutes at the bottom of the 12-meter-deep main pool, his body was retrieved but he could not be revived. The park initially characterized the death as an "accident" and claimed that the body showed no signs of violence, but the subsequent autopsy report stated that Martinez died due to grave injuries sustained by an orca attack, including multiple compression fractures, tears to vital organs, and the bite marks of the animal on his body.<ref>{{cite web|author=M. Á. Montero / Santa Cruz De Tenerife |url=http://www.abc.es/20101003/comunidad-canarias/orca-keto-ataco-causo-20101003.html |title=La orca "Keto" sí atacó y causó la muerte de Alexis, el adiestrador del Loro Parque |publisher=ABC.es |date= |accessdate=April 29, 2014}}</ref> During the investigation into the death of Alexis Martinez, it came to light that the park had also mischaracterized to the public a 2007 incident with Tekoa, the other male, and claimed it was also an accident rather than an attack.<ref>{{cite web|author=Moisés Á. Montero / Puerto De La Cruz |url=http://www.abc.es/20101101/comunidad-canarias/responsables-orcas-reconoce-agresion-20101101.html |title=Uno de los responsables de las orcas reconoce la "agresión" de "Tekoa" en 2007 |publisher=ABC.es |date= |accessdate=April 29, 2014}}</ref>
The only recorded injury of a human by an orca in the wild happened in 1972 at Point Sur, California. <ref>{{Cite news|url=http://orcazine.com/in-the-jaws-of-an-orca/|title=In the jaws of an orca - ORCAZINE|date=2016-02-29|work=ORCAZINE|access-date=2018-11-17|language=en-US}}</ref>
===Aggression between captive orcas=== One infamous incident of killer whale aggression took place in August 1989, when the dominant female Icelandic killer whale at SeaWorld San Diego, [[Kandu V]], attempted to "rake" a female newcomer named [[Corky (killer whale)|Corky]]. Raking is a way orcas show dominance by forcefully scratching at another with their teeth. Kandu charged at Corky, attempting to rake her, missed and continued swimming into the back pool, where she ended up ramming the wall, rupturing an artery in her jaw. The crowd was quickly ushered out of the stadium. Forty-five minutes later Kandu V sank to the bottom of the pool and died.<ref>[http://www.orca-zone.com/aboutorcas/corkysstory.html "Corky's Story"] {{webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20120910135912/http://www.orca-zone.com/aboutorcas/corkysstory.html |date=September 10, 2012 }} The Orca Zone. Retrieved September 3, 2014.</ref><ref>[https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http://www.geocities.com/hyena2_18/KANDU5_PAGE&date=2009-10-26+00:17:55 "Kandu 5 Page"] GeoCities. Retrieved September 3, 2014.</ref>
[[Kanduke]], a male captured from T pod in British Columbia, Canada in August 1975, often fought with a younger Icelandic male named Kotar. The aggression became increasingly serious, leading to an incident in which Kotar bit a part of Kanduke's genitals and caused an infection. It is not known if such serious aggression and injury would occur in the open seas.<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20091025114033/http://geocities.com/orca2000uk/Kanduke.html "Kanduke"] Orca Spirit. Retrieved September 3, 2014.</ref>
===Early pregnancy and related issues=== Captive killer whales often give birth at a much younger age than in the wild, sometimes as young as age seven. The young mothers may have difficulty raising their offspring. The calves have a relatively low survival rate, though some have lived into adulthood.
[[Corky (killer whale)|Corky (II)]], a female from the [[A5 Pod]] in [[British Columbia]], [[Canada]] became the first killer whale to become pregnant in captivity, giving birth on February 28, 1977. The calf died after 18 days. Corky went on to give birth six more times, but the longest surviving calf, Kiva, lived only 47 days.<ref>[http://orcalab.org/2008/12/08/corkys-saddest-day-december-11th-2008/ "Corky's saddest day"] Orca Lab. Retrieved September 3, 2014.</ref> SeaWorld has attracted criticism over its continued captivity of Corky II from the [[Born Free Foundation]], which wants her returned to the wild.<ref>{{cite web|author=UK |url=http://www.bornfree.org.uk/animals/orca/projects/captivity-issues/ |title=Behind the bars – Orca in captivity |publisher=Bornfree.org.uk |date= |accessdate=April 29, 2014}}</ref>
A killer whale named [[Katina (whale)|Katina]], captured near Iceland at about three years of age in October 1978, became pregnant in early spring of 1984 at SeaWorld San Diego and gave birth in September 1985 to a female named [[Kalina (whale)|Kalina]]. Although ten years was an extremely young age for a killer whale to become a mother, Kalina was the first killer whale calf to be successfully born and raised in captivity.<ref>[http://www.wdcs.org/submissions_bin/orcareport.pdf "Captive Orcas 'Dying to Entertain You'"] Whale and Dolphin Conservation Society. Retrieved February 15, 2009.</ref> In turn, Kalina gave birth at only seven and a half years of age to her first calf, a male named [[List of captive orcas#Keet|Keet]].<ref name="Kalina"/>
[[Gudrun (whale)|Gudrun]] was an Icelandic female caught in the 1970s. In 1993, she gave birth to Nyar, a female who was both mentally and physically ill, and who Gudrun tried to drown during several shows. Nyar died from an illness a few months later. Gudrun died in 1996 from stillbirth complications.<ref>[https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http://www.geocities.com/orca2000uk/Gudrun.html&date=2009-10-26+00:03:05 "Gudrun"] GeoCities. Retrieved February 12, 2009.</ref><ref name=Dolfinarium2008>Website Dolfinarium, Downloaded on November 5, 2008, from http://www.dolfinarium.nl/index.php?do=content&id=210 {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090219032741/http://www.dolfinarium.nl/index.php?do=content&id=210 |date=February 19, 2009 }}</ref>
[[Taima (whale)|Taima]] is a transient/Icelandic hybrid female killer whale born in captivity to Gudrun in 1989.<ref>[http://www.seaworld.org/whats-new/znn/2007/march/seaworld-welcomes-newest.htm SeaWorld Welcomes Newest "Pea" to Pod], press release, SeaWorld Orlando, March 12, 2007. Retrieved June 6, 2007. {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080517162034/http://www.seaworld.org/whats-new/znn/2007/march/seaworld-welcomes-newest.htm |date=May 17, 2008 }}</ref> Trainers believe that Gudrun's behavior towards Nyar may have confused Taima, as she may have learned by example that this was how to raise a calf. In May 1998, Taima gave birth to a male calf named Sumar. They were separated when he was about eight months old because of the aggression between them. On one occasion while performing, Taima started biting Sumar and throwing him out of the pool onto the [[animal trainer|trainer]]'s platform. She then slid out herself, and continued to bite him. In November 2000, Taima gave birth to a male named Tekoa. The two were separated after only nine months due to aggression between them.<ref>[http://www.freewebs.com/beyondtheblue/taima.htm "Beyond the Blue: Taima"] Free Webs. Retrieved February 12, 2009. {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090307135231/http://www.freewebs.com/beyondtheblue/taima.htm |date=March 7, 2009 }}</ref><ref>[http://www.freewebs.com/beyondtheblue/sumar.htm "Sumar"] Beyond the Blue. Retrieved February 12, 2009. {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081009062626/http://www.freewebs.com/beyondtheblue/sumar.htm |date=October 9, 2008 }}</ref> On March 12, 2007, Taima gave birth to her third calf, Malia. Taima seemed to be a better mother this time, and no notable occurrences of aggression were reported; this may be in part due to the fact that Kalina acted as "aunt" to Malia and helped Taima to look after her. Kalina was a very experienced mother and would often be kept with Malia, while Taima was given time with her mate, Tilikum. Taima died in 2010 during the birthing process of her fourth calf. The calf, fathered by Tilikum, was stillborn.
[[Kayla (whale)|Kayla]], a killer whale born in captivity, gave birth to her first calf on October 9, 2005, a female named Halyn. Kayla rejected her calf, perhaps because she had never been exposed to a young calf before and did not know how to deal with it. Halyn was moved to a special animal care facility to be hand raised. Halyn died unexpectedly on June 15, 2008.<ref name="WOAI">{{cite web|url=http://www.woai.com/news/local/story.aspx?content_id=F016E77F-495E-4F8D-80D0-C067CAF7B562&gsa=true= |title=Killer whale at SeaWorld San Antonio dies |accessdate=June 15, 2008 |date= |work= |publisher=[[Dallas Morning News]] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090308112825/http://www.woai.com/news/local/story.aspx?content_id=F016E77F-495E-4F8D-80D0-C067CAF7B562&gsa=true%3D |archivedate=March 8, 2009 |df= }}</ref>
On October 13, 2010, Kohana, an eight-year-old female killer whale, gave birth to a male calf at Loro Parque's "Orca Ocean" exhibit after a four-hour labor. The calf weighed about 150 kilograms (330 lb), and was two meters (6 ft 7 in) long. Kohana has yet to establish a "maternal bond" with her calf, forcing trainers to take the first steps in hand rearing him. The outcome of this pregnancy was not considered surprising, since Kohana was separated from her own mother, Takara, at three years of age, and was never able to learn about maternal care, compounded by the fact that she spent the formative years of her life surrounded by the three other juvenile killer whales at Loro Parque.
