{{lowercase title}} {{Infobox website | name = isoHunt | logo = [[File:Logo of isoHunt.svg|150px]] | screenshot = [[File:isoHunt screenshot.png|center|255px]] | caption = ''isoHunt logo and screenshot of homepage'' | url = {{URL|isohunt.to}}{{ref label|n1|α}} | ip = | commercial = No | type = Torrent index | registration = Optional; mandatory for uploading | language = English | num_users = | content license = [[Free access]] | owner = isoHunt Inc. (Gary Fung) | author = Gary Fung | launch date = {{start date and age|2003|1}} | revenue = [[Online advertising]]
[[Donation]]s
[[Paid membership]] | alexa = {{IncreaseNegative}} 12,304 ({{as of|2017|November|alt=November 2017}}){{cite web|url= http://www.alexa.com/siteinfo/isohunt.to |title= Isohunt.to Site Info | publisher= [[Alexa Internet]] |accessdate= 2016-04-01 }} | current status = Offline{{ref label|n1|α}} | footnotes = {{note label|n1|α}}{{small|Functional [[#IsoHunt_clones|clones]] have been created by others}} }} {{fsb}} '''isoHunt''' is an [[website|online]] [[torrent file]]s [[index (publishing)|index]] and repository, where visitors can browse, search, download or upload torrents of various [[digital content]] of mostly entertainment nature. The current incarnation arose as a resurrection of the original site that was taken down by legal action from the [[MPAA]]; it is not associated in any way with the old staff or owners of the site, and is to be understood as a separate continuation.{{cite web|author1=Ernesto|title=IsoHunt Resurrected Less Than Two Weeks After $110 Million MPAA Deal|url=http://torrentfreak.com/isohunt-resurrected-less-than-two-weeks-after-110-million-mpaa-deal-131029/|website=[[TorrentFreak]]|accessdate=4 June 2015|date=29 October 2013}} It originated in 2003 as isohunt.com website for [[Direct Client-to-Client|IRC files]] search and reached over 13.7 million{{cite web|url=http://isohunt.com/forum/viewtopic.php?t=115374 |title=Toolbar and Stats |publisher=Isohunt.com |date= |accessdate=2013-10-19}} torrents in its database and 20 million [[Peer-to-peer|peers]] from [[index (search engine)|indexed]] torrents.{{cite web|url=http://isohunt.com/stats.php?mode=btSites |title=BitTorrent Sites Statistics |publisher=Isohunt.com |date= |accessdate=2009-10-19}} With 7.4 million unique visitors {{as of|2006|5|lc=on}}, isoHunt was one of the most popular [[BitTorrent]] search engines. Thousands of torrents were added to and deleted from it every day. Users of isoHunt performed over 40 million unique searches per month. On October 19, 2008, isoHunt passed the 1 [[petabyte]] mark for torrents indexed globally. The site was the third most popular BitTorrent site {{as of|2008|lc=on}}.{{cite web|url=http://torrentfreak.com/top-10-torrent-sites-of-2008-081228/ |title=Top 10 Most Popular Torrent Sites of 2008 (stats from Alexa and Compete) |publisher=Torrentfreak.com |date=2008-12-28 |accessdate=2009-10-19}} According to isoHunt, the total amount of shared content was more than 14.11 [[petabytes]] {{as of|2012|06|13|lc=on|df=US}}.{{cite web|url=http://isohunt.com/|title=Isohunt Home|date=2009-11-03|accessdate=2011-09-29|publisher=isohunt}} The site came to an end when the legal battles that isoHunt's founder had been in for years with conglomerates of [[IP rights]] holders over allegations of [[copyright infringement|copyright infringing]] came to a head. A settlement with the [[MPAA]] was reached in 2013, stipulating a $110 million reimbursement for damages and the site's closure that followed on October 21, 2013.{{cite web|author1=Ernesto|title=IsoHunt Shuts Down After $110 Million Settlement With The MPAA|url=http://torrentfreak.com/isohunt-shuts-down-after-110-million-settlement-with-the-mpaa-131017/|website=[[TorrentFreak]]|accessdate=4 June 2015|date=17 October 2013}} By the end of October 2013 however, two sites with content presumably mirrored from isohunt.com were reported in media. One of them— isohunt.to became a de facto replacement of the original site. == History == isoHunt was founded in January 2003 by Gary Fung, a Canadian national. Its name is derived from the term [[ISO image]], used to describe a 1:1 soft copy of a disk (typically a CD or DVD). On February 23, 2006, the [[Motion Picture Association of America|Motion Picture Association of America (MPAA)]] issued a press release stating they were suing isoHunt for copyright infringement. On September 2, 2009, isoHunt announced the launch of a spinoff site, hexagon.cc.{{cite web|url=http://torrentfreak.com/isohunt-launches-social-bittorrent-site-090902/ |title=isoHunt Launches ‘Social’ BitTorrent Site |publisher=torrentfreak.com |date= |accessdate=2009-12-28}} The goal of hexagon.cc was to have a place for social groups based on certain niches to share specific content relevant to their interests. It is down until further notice. In early 2010, users in the US and along south eastern Canada were redirected to a stripped-down version called isoHunt Lite in order to remove some of the factors that were used in determining liability for infringement; however, full access was restored in early 2012. In October 2013 Isohunt announced it would shut down indefinitely. After years of court battles over copyright infringement with the MPAA, Isohunt agreed to a settlement. Under the terms of the settlement Isohunt will shut down the site, and close three other sites that redirect to the Isohunt domain: Podtropolis, TorrentBox, and Edtk-it.com. Fung also agreed to pay $110 million in damages. The site was shut down on October 21, 2013, two days earlier than originally planned, leaving a farewell message from Gary Fung that also explained that the rush was to prevent backup activity — possibly the one reported to have been started by [[ArchiveTeam]].{{cite web |url=http://torrentfreak.com/archiveteam-works-hard-to-avert-isohunt-data-massacre-131020/ |title=ArchiveTeam Works Hard to Avert isoHunt Data Massacre |date=20 October 2013 |website=TorrentFreak |accessdate=21 October 2013}} == Legal == === Correspondence with the MPAA === Selected items of email correspondence between Gary Fung and the [[MPAA]] have been posted on isoHunt.com.{{cite web|author=IH |url=http://isohunt.com/forum/viewtopic.php?t=9273 |title=isoHunt Forum — Letters from MPAA |publisher=Isohunt.com |date=2003-01-21 |accessdate=2009-10-19 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101007095929/http://isohunt.com/forum/viewtopic.php?t=9273 |archivedate=October 7, 2010 }} === Lawsuit === In February 2006 it was announced that the [[MPAA]] had launched legal proceedings against isoHunt, [[TorrentBox]], [[TorrentSpy]], [[ed2k-it]], and several other BitTorrent indexing or tracker sites, alleging that these sites facilitate copyright infringement. On February 28, 2006 a lawsuit was filed against Gary Fung in the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York. Fung stands to oppose the [[Motion Picture Association of America|MPAA]] on legal grounds.{{cite web|url=http://isohunt.com/forum/viewtopic.php?t=126788 |title=isoHunt Forums :: View topic — isoHunt tells court why Hollywood is wrong |publisher=Isohunt.com |date= |accessdate=2009-10-19}} On August 18, 2006, Judge Stanton granted a motion for case transfer from New York to California on the grounds of inconvenienced parties and similar cases already filed in the District Court of Central California. On December 21, 2009, the court granted the MPAA's motion for [[summary judgment]], finding isoHunt and Fung liable for copyright infringement on the theory of inducement. The MPAA had presented evidence showing that the majority of content linked to on IsoHunt was infringing content, that the search engine was tuned to assist users in finding infringing works, and that Fung himself had made remarks suggesting the purpose of the site was to allow users to download infringing content. The court found that IsoHunt had not presented any satisfactory evidence to counter these claims, and at its core it was merely an "evolutionary modification" of [[Napster]] and [[Grokster]], two P2P systems that had previously been held liable for inducing copyright infringement.{{cite web|url=https://arstechnica.com/tech-policy/news/2009/12/judge-slams-isohunt-infringement-old-wine-in-a-new-bottle.ars | title =isoHunt loses big: infringement "old wine in a new bottle"| author=John Timmer| publisher=Ars Technica}} As a result, the court went on to issue a permanent injunction prohibiting IsoHunt to continue indexing and linking to infringing content.{{cite web|url=https://arstechnica.com/tech-policy/news/2010/05/1-down-5-to-go-isohunt-neutered-by-us-judge.ars|title=1 down, 5 to go? isoHunt neutered by US judge|author=Nate Anderson|publisher=Ars Technica}} The case on appeal, dubbed ''[[Columbia Pictures Industries, Inc. v. Fung]]'', upheld the district court's findings on copyright infringement, but found that the injunction was overly burdensome to the extent it could prevent Fung from seeking legitimate employment, as certain provisions in the injunction would have prevented Fung from working in any technology company whose services could be used to infringe copyrighted content even if those companies were not engaged in copyright infringement. === DMCA takedown notices === IsoHunt has a history of complying with [[DMCA]] [[takedown notice]]s, and has worked with various copyright owners in the past, such as the [[RIAA]] and [[Microsoft]]. The site uses an [[ex-gratia]] takedown process modelled on the DMCA, even though the servers were relocated to [[Canada]] in January 2007 where the DMCA does not apply.{{cite web|url=http://isohunt.com/dmca-copyright.php |title=isoHunt DMCA Copyright Policy |publisher=Isohunt.com |date=2007-01-22 |accessdate=2009-10-19}}[http://www.cdfreaks.com/news/isoHunt-gets-shutdown-by-ISP-and-moves-to-Canada.html isoHunt gets shutdown by ISP and moves to Canada] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080906182434/http://www.cdfreaks.com/news/isoHunt-gets-shutdown-by-ISP-and-moves-to-Canada.html |date=2008-09-06 }}, CD Freaks === Lawsuit against the CRIA === On September 8, 2008 Gary Fung announced on the isoHunt front page{{cite web|url=http://isohunt.com|title=isohunt.com|author=|date=|work=isohunt.com}} that he had made a preemptive move against an impending lawsuit from the [[Canadian Recording Industry Association|CRIA]] by filing a petition to the Supreme Court of British Columbia. Fung argues that isoHunt is merely a search engine to find torrents that are scattered around the web, much the same as [[Google]] or any other search engine can be used in the same way.{{cite web|url=http://isohunt.com/forum/viewtopic.php?t=141381 |title=isoHunt Forums :: View topic — isoHunt sues CRIA on legality of search engines |publisher=Isohunt.com |date= |accessdate=2009-10-19 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090216031028/http://isohunt.com/forum/viewtopic.php?t=141381 |archivedate=February 16, 2009 }} === Internet service providers === On January 16, 2007, isoHunt was taken off-line, stating "Lawyers from our primary [[ISP]] decided to pull our plug without any advance notice". After a major hardware upgrade,{{cite web|url=http://isohunt.com/forum/viewtopic.php?t=80731 |title=Hardware upgrade after servers move to Canada |publisher=Isohunt.com |date= |accessdate=2009-10-19 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090622030322/http://isohunt.com/forum/viewtopic.php?t=80731 |archivedate=June 22, 2009 }} the site resumed normal operation by January 22, 2007, although experiencing several brief periods of subsequent downtime due to server changes. On July/August 2013, [[Federazione Industria Musicale Italiana|Federation of the Italian Music Industry]] obtained an order from the Court of Milan which demands [[Internet service provider|ISP]]s to block isoHunt's domain and IP address.{{cite web|url=https://torrentfreak.com/isohunt-blocked-by-court-order-following-music-industry-demand-130801/|title=IsoHunt Blocked By Court Order Following Music Industry Demand|author=|date=|work=TorrentFreak}} === Shutdown as part of settlement with MPAA === On October 17, 2013 [[Variety.com]] announced the website isoHunt would shut down by Oct. 23, 2013, as part of a settlement in a massive copyright infringement suit filed by Hollywood studios, agreeing to pay $110 million for claims that the site induced the violation of copyrighted movies and TV shows although isoHunt never hosted such content. The settlement terms included a $110 million judgment against isoHunt and its owner, Gary Fung, ending a seven-year legal battle over its operations.{{cite web|url=https://variety.com/2013/biz/news/isohunt-to-shut-down-as-part-of-settlement-with-studios-1200734509/|title=isoHunt To Shut Down As Part of Settlement With Studios - Variety|author=Ted Johnson|date=|work=Variety}} According to court documents cited by the BBC, Fung's company will likely be able to pay only between two and four million dollars though.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/technology-24580130|title=Piracy site IsoHunt to shut down and pay $110m|author=|date=|work=BBC News}} The site shut down on 21 October 2013, 2 days earlier than the announced date, leaving a note from Gary Fung and a link to a [[YouTube]] "trailer for the movie [[Terminator Salvation]]" that is actually a [[Rickroll]].{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/life-style/gadgets-and-tech/news/isohunt-shuts-early-to-prevent-archiving-owner-gary-fung-rickrolls-fans-8897103.html|title=IsoHunt shuts early to prevent archiving, owner Gary Fung rickrolls|author=James Vincent|date=25 October 2013|work=The Independent}} {{quotation|'''Initiating Self Destruct''' This is it. We are shutting down isoHunt services a little early. I'm told there was this Internet archival team that wants to make historical copy of our .torrent files, I'm honoured that people thinks our site is worthy of historical preservation, but the truth is about 95% of those .torrent files can be found off Google regardless and mostly have been indexed from other BitTorrent sites in the first place. So I might as well do a proper send-off to you dear isoHunt users, before final shutdown sequence on Tuesday. It's been an adventure in the last 10.5 years working on isoHunt, a privilege working with some of the smartest guys I've worked with, and my life won't be the same without it. For what I'm working on next, please look up my blog on Google and follow me there. Because as the Terminator would say with a German accent, '''''I'll be backkk'''''.|Gary Fung{{cite web|url=http://torrentfreak.com/isohunt-shuts-down-early-to-block-backup-plan-131021/|title=isoHunt Shuts Down Early to Block Backup Plan|author=|date=|work=TorrentFreak}}}} ==Technical details== In the beginning of 2007, isoHunt restructured its server setup and bought mostly new hardware for the cluster that operates the site. The cluster had a total of 34 [[AMD Opteron]] cores, 70 GB in [[RAM]] and 30 [[hard drive]]s ranging from [[SATA]]s to 15,000 [[Revolutions per minute|rpm]] [[SCSI]]s.{{cite web|url=http://www.isohunt.com/forum/viewtopic.php?p=208021#208021 |title=Technical Details |publisher=Isohunt.com |date= |accessdate=2009-10-19}} The network started with a [[D-Link]] [[network switch|switch]] but due to multiple failures, isoHunt moved to a [[Force10]] switch. IsoHunt was uplinked through Neutral Data Centers Corp to a mix of bandwidth providers. == IsoHunt clones == {{lowercase title}} {{Infobox website | name = Isohunt.to | logo = [[File:Logo of isoHunt.svg|150px]] | logocaption = Isohunt.to uses logo of original isoHunt | screenshot = | caption = | url = {{URL|isohunt.to}} [https://web.archive.org/web/20131014003025/http://www.isohunt.com/ oldpiratebay.org]{{ref label|n2|α}} | slogan = | commercial = No | type = Torrent index | registration = Optional; mandatory for uploading | language = English | num_users = | content license = [[Free access]] | owner = [[Anonymous work|anonymous]] | author = [[Anonymous work|anonymous]] | launch date = October 2013 | revenue = [[Online advertising]]
[[Donation]]s | alexa = {{DecreasePositive}} 1,768 ({{as of|2015|3|10|alt=March 2015}}){{cite web|url= http://www.alexa.com/siteinfo/Isohunt.to |title= Isohunt.to Site Info | publisher= [[Alexa Internet]] |accessdate= 2014-12-19 }} | current status = Online | footnotes = {{note label|n2|α}}{{small|Taken offline when [[The Pirate Bay]] came online in Jan 2015}} }} On October 30, 2013, two weeks following the shutdown of the original website, a group of people claiming to be dedicated to isoHunt's continuance brought a near-identical [[Website mirror|clone]] of the original website online, accessible via isohunt.to.{{cite web|last=Kerr|first=Dara|title=Isohunt BitTorrent site rises from the dead as Isohunt.to|url=http://news.cnet.com/8301-1023_3-57610145-93/isohunt-bittorrent-site-rises-from-the-dead-as-isohunt.to/|work=CNET Article|accessdate=31 October 2013}} Former staff member of original isoHunt has made it clear that the team behind isohunt.com has not been involved in any way in 'resurrection' of isoHunt. Another site, isohunt.ee, has also been reported to be an unauthorized clone of the original site.{{cite web|url=https://arstechnica.com/tech-policy/2013/10/not-even-two-weeks-after-shutdown-bittorrent-search-site-isohunt-is-back/|title=Not even two weeks after shutdown, clone of BitTorrent search site isoHunt opens|author=|date=|work=Ars Technica}} ArchiveTeam have stated that they are not affiliated with any mirrors of isoHunt. It is branded in isoHunt's style, featuring both a ghostly blue theme and the isoHunt logo.{{cite web|title=OldPirateBay.org Search By IsoHunt Team|url=http://blog.isohunt.to/370/|accessdate=17 December 2014}} The team stated that they would gladly take their copy of the site down if and when the original Pirate Bay came back online, which occurred on January 31, 2015. === The Open Bay === On December 19, 2014, isoHunt.to released a tool called The Open Bay at [https://web.archive.org/web/20131014003025/http://www.isohunt.com/ Openbay.isohunt.to], providing original source code and additional tools in order to allow users to deploy their own version of The Pirate Bay website.{{Cite web| title = isoHunt now lets anyone launch their own version of The Pirate Bay| author = Protalinski, Emil| work = VentureBeat| date = 19 December 2014| accessdate = 19 December 2014| url = https://venturebeat.com/2014/12/19/isohunt-now-lets-anyone-launch-their-own-version-of-the-pirate-bay/ }} == See also == * [[Comparison of BitTorrent sites]] * [[Demonoid]] * [[International Intellectual Property Alliance]] * [[Peer-to-peer file sharing]] == References == {{Reflist|2}} == External links == {{Wikinews|Wikinews interviews Gary Fung from isoHunt}} *{{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131014003025/http://www.isohunt.com |date=October 14, 2013 |title=IsoHunt }} {{BitTorrent}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Isohunt}} [[Category:Internet properties established in 2003]] [[Category:Defunct websites]] [[Category:Internet properties disestablished in 2013]] [[Category:Internet services shut down by a legal challenge]] [[Category:Notorious markets]] [[Category:Defunct BitTorrent websites]]

The '''Law of Jersey''' has been influenced by several different legal traditions, in particular [[Norman law|Norman customary law]], [[English common law#Common law|English common law]] and modern [[Law of France|French civil law]].<ref name="ref1">See generally {{cite book|author=S Nicolle|title=The Origin and Development of Jersey law: an Outline Guide|edition=5th|location=St Helier|publisher=Jersey and Guernsey Law Review|year=2009|ISBN=978-0-9557611-3-3}} and {{cite web|url=http://www.lawinstitute.ac.je/default.asp?contentID=629 |publisher=Institute of Law |location=Jersey |title=Study Guide on Jersey Legal System and Constitutional Law |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131228104105/http://www.lawinstitute.ac.je/default.asp?contentID=629 |archivedate=2013-12-28 |df= }}</ref> The [[Jersey|Bailiwick of Jersey]] is a separate [[Jurisdiction (area)|jurisdiction]] from that of the United Kingdom, and is also distinct from that of the other [[Channel Islands]] such as [[Guernsey]], although they do share some historical developments. Jersey's [[List of national legal systems|legal system]] is 'mixed' or '[[Legal pluralism|pluralistic]]', and sources of law are in French and English languages, although since the 1950s the main [[working language]] of the legal system is English.
== Sources of law ==
=== Legislation adopted by the States of Jersey === Jersey's legislature, the [[States of Jersey|States Assembly]] makes [[legislation]] affecting most areas of activity.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lawinstitute.ac.je/default.asp?contentID=629 |publisher=Institute of Law |title=Study Guide for Jersey Legal System and Constitutional Law, chapter 8 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131228104105/http://www.lawinstitute.ac.je/default.asp?contentID=629 |archivedate=2013-12-28 |df= }}</ref>
==== Laws ==== [[File:1771 onwards Jersey Recueil des Lois.jpg|thumb|''Recueil de Lois de Jersey'' from 1771]] The highest form of legislation made by the States is 'Laws'. If a proposed Law is likely to be controversial, the general desirability of having new legislation on the topic may be debated before the Law drafted. The procedure for making Laws is set out in the Standing Orders of the States of Jersey.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.jerseylaw.je/Law/lawsinforce/consolidated/16/16.800.15_StandingOrdersoftheStatesofJersey_RevisedEdition_1January2011.pdf|title=Standing Orders of the States of Jersey|date=1 January 2011}}; {{cite web|first=Lucy|last=Marsh-Smith|title=The Production of Legislation in the Crown Dependencies|year=2010|publisher=Jersey Law Review|url=http://www.jerseylaw.je/Publications/jerseylawreview/feb10/JLR1002_Marsh-Smith.aspx|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120316221553/http://www.jerseylaw.je/Publications/jerseylawreview/feb10/JLR1002_Marsh-Smith.aspx|archivedate=2012-03-16|df=}}</ref> Once the Law is in draft from, it starts the legislative process as a ''projet de loi'', which may be introduced to the States by a [[Cabinet of Jersey|Minister]], any States Member, a [[scrutiny panel]] or the Comité des [[Connétable (Jersey and Guernsey)|Connétables]]. At the stage known as 'first reading', the title of the projet is read out and the projet is 'lodged [[Greffier|au Greffe]]' providing a two to six week breathing space for Members to read the draft Law. Under Article 16 of the Human Rights (Jersey) Law 2000,<ref name="HRLaw">{{cite web|url=http://www.jerseylaw.je/Law/display.aspx?url=lawsinforce%5Chtm%5CLawFiles%5C2000%2FJersey_Law_19-2000.htm|title=Human Rights (Jersey) Law 2000|publisher=JerseyLaw|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131224110631/http://www.jerseylaw.je/Law/display.aspx?url=lawsinforce%5Chtm%5CLawFiles%5C2000%2FJersey_Law_19-2000.htm|archivedate=2013-12-24|df=}}</ref> the Minister or other person lodging the projet au Greffe must make a written statement that the provisions of the projet are compatible with [[ECHR|Convention rights]] or 'make a statement that although [he or she] is unable to make a statement of compatibility, [he or she] nevertheless wants the States to proceed with the projet'. At the next 'second reading' stage, there is a formal debate in the States chamber during which members consider the principle of the projet and then scrutinise the draft in detail. At 'third reading' stage there is an opportunity for minor drafting errors to be corrected. Finally, members vote to adopt the law.
The Law is then submitted via the [[Lieutenant Governor of Jersey|Lieutenant Governor]]'s office for transmission to London, where [[Politics of Jersey#Relations with the United Kingdom|officials]] in the [[Ministry of Justice (United Kingdom)|Ministry of Justice]] examine the Law. In 2010, the [[House of Commons Justice Committee]] was highly critical of the UK Government's approach, finding that 'The Islands are more than adequately advised by their own Law Officers and Parliamentary Counsel. It seems a strange use of Ministry of Justice resources ... to engage in a kind of legislative oversight which does not restrict itself to the constitutional grounds for scrutiny'.<ref>{{cite web|publisher=House of Commons Justice Committee|title=Crown Dependencies, 8th Report of 2009-10, HC 56-1, para 62|url=https://publications.parliament.uk/pa/cm200910/cmselect/cmjust/56/5607.htm#a6}}</ref> This process may take several months. In an unusual move in 2011, campaigners against a Law that sought to reduce the number of Senators in the States petitioned the Privy Council to advise the Queen to refuse Royal Assent.<ref>{{cite web|title=Save Senators plea reaches Privy Council|publisher=Jersey Evening Post|date=7 June 2011|url=http://www.thisisjersey.com/2011/06/07/save-senators-plea-reaches-privy-council/}}</ref> Once official scrutiny is complete in London, the Law is formally presented to Her Majesty for [[Royal Assent]] at a meeting of the [[Privy Council of the United Kingdom|Privy Council]], usually held at Buckingham Palace or Windsor Castle.
After a Law receives Royal Assent, the final step is for it be registered with the [[Royal Court of Jersey]]. At this point it is 'passed'. The Law is then brought into force at a date decided by the relevant Jersey minister. There may be a considerable delay between a Law being passed and it becoming legally effective if, for example, civil servants need to be trained, computer systems put in place or money found to pay for the new scheme.
Laws adopted and passed are published in print as ''Recueil de Lois'' de Jersey and online by the [[Jersey Legal Information Board]] on the Jersey Law<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.jerseylaw.je/Law/LawsInForce/default.aspx|title=Laws in Force|publisher=JerseyLaw|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120928234724/http://www.jerseylaw.je/Law/LawsInForce/default.aspx|archivedate=2012-09-28|df=}}</ref> website.
==== Other types of legislation ==== In Jersey, there are other types of legislation in addition to Laws.<ref>{{cite book | last1 = Institute of Law | title = Jersey Legal System and Constitutional Law | chapter = 8 | publisher = Institute of Law | year = 2011 | location = Jersey | url = http://www.lawinstitute.ac.je/downloads/2011.10.20%20Jersey%20Legal%20System%20-%20FINAL%20with%20ISBN.pdf | accessdate = 2012-03-27 | isbn = 978-1-908716-00-2 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20120314235510/http://www.lawinstitute.ac.je/downloads/2011.10.20%20Jersey%20Legal%20System%20-%20FINAL%20with%20ISBN.pdf | archivedate = 2012-03-14 | df = }}</ref> * '''Regulations''': these are used where a Law delegates to the States Assembly power to make legally binding rules to implement a named Law. * '''Triennial Regulations''': since the 18th century, the States of Jersey has had power to make provisional regulations of up to three years' duration. * '''Orders and Rules''': these are generally made by a Minister, within the scope of powers set out in a Law.
=== Customary law === Custom is a source of law in the Jersey legal system. It has been described as "the product of generally accepted usage and practice. It has no formal sanction or authority behind it other than the general consensus of opinion within the community".<ref>Snell v Beadle [2001] UKPC 5 at [16] http://www.bailii.org/uk/cases/UKPC/2001/5.html</ref> It differs from [[English common law]] where rules stated by a judge of a senior court are binding law ''because'' they are stated by a judge. In customary law, the role of the [[Judiciary of Jersey (list)|judiciary]] is to look for evidence of what is "generally accepted usage and practice".
Many rules of customary law have crystallised to such an extent (through repeated acknowledgment by the [[Royal Court of Jersey|Royal Court]] and in the way people conduct their affairs) that everyone accepts them as binding without discussion. The boundaries of the [[Parishes of Jersey|Parishes]], the existence of the office of [[Bailiff (Channel Islands)#Bailiff of Jersey|Bailiff]] and various rules relating to possession of land and inheritance fall into this category. Many rules of customary law are to be found discussed in the texts of the "Commentators" and the case law of the Jersey courts. Where the works of the commentators do not deal with situation, the Jersey courts look at factual evidence to work out is the "generally accepted usage and practice".<ref>See e.g. ''Moran v Deputy Registrar for the Parish of St Helier'' [2007] JRC 151 http://www.jerseylaw.je/Judgments/UnReportedJudgments/Documents/Display.aspx?url=2007/07-08-02_Moran_and_Kemp_and_The_Deputy_Registrar_for_St_Helier_151.htm {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120113055727/http://www.jerseylaw.je/Judgments/UnReportedJudgments/Documents/Display.aspx?url=2007%2F07-08-02_Moran_and_Kemp_and_The_Deputy_Registrar_for_St_Helier_151.htm |date=2012-01-13 }}</ref>
The customary law of the [[Duchy of Normandy]] is particularly influential as a source of law in Jersey, even though Jersey ceased to part of Normandy in 1204. Norman law developed in two main epochs–the "Ancienne coutume" (1199–1538) and the "Coutume reformée" (1538–1804).
==== Ancienne coutume of Normandy ==== The northern and western regions of Medieval Europe "were a patchwork of territorial areas in which the main source of law was customs, usages and practices which had become relatively fixed and settled".<ref>{{cite book | last1 = Institute of Law | title = Jersey Legal System and Constitutional Law | chapter = Chapter 2 | publisher = Institute of Law | year = 2011 | location = Jersey | url = http://www.lawinstitute.ac.je/downloads/2011.10.20%20Jersey%20Legal%20System%20-%20FINAL%20with%20ISBN.pdf | accessdate = 2012-03-27 | isbn = 978-1-908716-00-2 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20120314235510/http://www.lawinstitute.ac.je/downloads/2011.10.20%20Jersey%20Legal%20System%20-%20FINAL%20with%20ISBN.pdf | archivedate = 2012-03-14 | df = }}</ref> Norman law was based on oral tradition and repeated practices in [[Feudal]] society.<ref>{{Cite web | last = Les Normands, peuple d'Europe | first = | authorlink = | title = Norman customary law | work = Le patrimonie normand européen, 10th - 12th siècles | publisher = | url = http://www.mondes-normands.fr/angleterre/cultures/GB_FR/culture1_7.htm | doi = | accessdate = 27 August 2011}}</ref> The earliest known written account of the Ancienne coutume of Normandy is the "Très-ancienne coutume", first set down in [[Latin]] manuscript around 1199 to 1223. It was translated into French, probably in about 1230.<ref>{{Cite web| last =Harvard Law School| first =| authorlink =| title =French Coutumes| work =| publisher =| url =http://www.law.harvard.edu/library/special/exhibits/digital/french-coutumes.html| doi =| accessdate =27 August 2011| deadurl =yes| archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20100812100333/http://www.law.harvard.edu/library/special/exhibits/digital/french-coutumes.html| archivedate =12 August 2010| df =}} and {{Cite web| last =| first =| authorlink =| title =Rechtsgeschiedenis Blog (Legal history with a Dutch view)| work =Centuries of law in Normandy| publisher =| url =http://rechtsgeschiedenis.wordpress.com/2011/02/12/centuries-of-law-in-normandy/| format =| doi =| accessdate =27 August 2011}}</ref> It is thought to be the work of scholars or court officials, designed to be a manual for legal practitioners.<ref>{{Cite book | last = Besnier | first = Robert | authorlink = | title = La coutume de Normandie: histoire externe | publisher = Librairie du Recueil Sirey, société anonyme | series = | volume = | edition = | year = 1935 | location = | pages = | language = | url = | doi = | id = | isbn = | mr = | zbl = | jfm = }}</ref> A modern edition was compiled from various sources in 1903 by Professor E.J. Tardiff.<ref>{{Cite book | last = Tardif | first = Ernest Joseph | authorlink = | title = Coutumiers de Normandie V1, Part: Le Tres Ancien Coutumier de Normandie | publisher = Kessinger Publishing | series = | volume = | edition = 2010 reprint | year = 1903 | location = | pages = | language = | url = | doi = | id = | isbn =978-1-167-84556-7 | mr = | zbl = | jfm = }}</ref>
[[File:Le Rouille commentary on Maine customary law 1535.jpg|thumb|left|Le Rouillée's 1535 commentary on the customs of [[Maine (province)|Maine]]]] Of more importance to Jersey law is "Le Grand Coutume de Normandie" written in the period 1245-58, originally in Latin manuscript (''Summa de Legibus'').<ref>{{Cite web| last =Archives départementales de Seine-Maritime| first =| authorlink =| title =Tresors d'archives| work =Grand coutumier de Normandie, manuscrit sur parchemin, fin XVe siècle| publisher =| url =http://www.archivesdepartementales76.net/tresors/10-grand-coutumier-de-normandie-manuscrit-sur-parchemin-fin-xve-siecle.html| doi =| accessdate =| deadurl =yes| archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20120318013115/http://www.archivesdepartementales76.net/tresors/10-grand-coutumier-de-normandie-manuscrit-sur-parchemin-fin-xve-siecle.html| archivedate =2012-03-18| df =}}</ref> The first printed version dates to 1438. It sets out the law and practice of Normandy in the form of 125 articles. It is probable that the original compiler "was an individual legal practitioner or scholar, rather than it being in any sense an official work".<ref>{{Cite book | last = Everard | first = Judith Ann | authorlink = | title = The Laws and Customs by Which the Duchy of Normandy is Ruled: Le Grand Coutumier de Normandy | publisher = Jersey and Guernsey Law Review Ltd | series = | volume = | edition = | year = 2009 | location = | pages = xxv | language = | url = | doi = | id = | isbn =978-0-9557611-4-0 | mr = | zbl = | jfm = }}</ref> When in 1309 [[Edward II of England]] sent Justices to Jersey, the people of Jersey were "asked by what law they claimed to be governed, the law of England, of Normandy, or by some special customs of their own? They answered 'By the law of Normandy, and referred the Justices to the ''Summa of Malcael'' [the Jersey name for the Grand Coutumier], where the Norman laws are well embodied'... But they added, and this a clause that caused much trouble later, 'except that we have certain customs used in this island from time immemorial".<ref>{{Cite book | last = Syvret | first = Marguerite | authorlink = |author2=Joan Stevens | title = Balleine's History of Jersey | publisher = Phillimore | series = | volume = | edition = | year = 1981 | location = Chichester | page = 38 | language = | url = | doi = | id = | isbn =0-85033-413-6 | mr = | zbl = | jfm = }}</ref>
In the 16th century, two commentaries on the Grand Coutumier, written in Normandy, have been influential in Jersey law. [[:fr:Guillaume Le Rouillé|Guillaume Rouillé of Alençon]] (also known as Le Rouillé) was the author of ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=3-xCAAAAcAAJ&dq=intitle%3ALe%20intitle%3AGrant%20intitle%3ACoustumier&pg=PT3#v=onepage&q&f=false Le Grant Coustumier du pays & duché de Normendie : tres utile & profitable a tous practiciens]'' (1534; 1539). He also produced commentary on the neighbouring province of [[Maine (province)|Maine]] (pictured).
Guillaume Terrien's ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=xYaA_5KCB04C&dq=Commentaires%20du%20droit%20civil%20tant%20public%20que%20priv%C3%A9%20observ%C3%A9%20au%20pays%20et%20Duch%C3%A9%20de%20Normandie&pg=PP3#v=onepage&q&f=false Commentaires du droit civil, tant public que privé, observé au pays et Duché de Normandie]'' was first published in 1574. Dawes explains: "Terrien’s own work comprised the selecting of texts from the ''Grand Coutumier'', putting them into an order which suited his scheme (even to the point of cutting and pasting quite disparate texts) and then commenting on the resulting amalgam. To this commentary a further author added notes headed 'Additio', more often than not in Latin".<ref>{{Cite journal| last =Dawes| first =Gordon| authorlink =| title =A note on Guillaume Terrien and his work| journal =Jersey and Guernsey Law Review| volume =| issue =| pages =| publisher =Jersey and Guernsey Law Review Ltd| location =| year =2007| language =| url =http://www.jerseylaw.je/Publications/jerseylawreview/feb07/JLR0702_Dawes.aspx| jstor =| issn =| doi =| id =| mr =| zbl =| jfm =| accessdate =27 August 2011| deadurl =yes| archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20120113055355/http://www.jerseylaw.je/Publications/jerseylawreview/feb07/JLR0702_Dawes.aspx| archivedate =13 January 2012| df =}}</ref>
Two modern versions of the text of the Grand Coutumier have been produced. The first was by [[Jurat]] William Laurence de Gruchy entitled ''L’Ancienne Coutume de Normandie: Réimpression, éditée avec de légères annotations'' (1881), based on Le Rouillé’s 1539 edition, using a double-column format setting out the Latin and French texts side by side.<ref>{{Cite book | last = de Gruchy | first = William Lawrence | authorlink = | title = L' Ancienne Coutume de Normandie: Réimpression Éditée Avec de Légères Annotations | publisher = BiblioBazaar | series = | volume = | edition = print on demand | year = 1881 | location = | page = 448 | language = | url = | doi = | id = | isbn =978-1-146-20215-2 | mr = | zbl = | jfm = }}</ref> In 2009, an English translation of the Latin text by J.A. Everard was published.<ref>{{Cite book | last = Everard | first = Judith Ann | authorlink = | title = The Laws and Customs by Which the Duchy of Normandy is Ruled: Le Grand Coutumier de Normandy | publisher = Jersey and Guernsey Law Review Ltd | series = | volume = | edition = | year = 2009 | location = | pages = | language = | url = | doi = | id = | isbn =978-0-9557611-4-0 | mr = | zbl = | jfm = }}</ref>
==== Coutume Reformée of Normandy ==== [[File:Berault_Coutume_Reformée_3rd_edn_1620.jpg|thumb|Berault's 1620 commentary]] The second period in the development of Norman custom was between 1583 and 1804 and is known as the ''Coutume reformée'' (the reformed custom). In 1453, [[Charles VII of France]] issued orders that all the customary laws of France should be "redacted", in other words set out systematically and approved under royal authority. The [[Duchy of Normandy]] was the last part of France to comply with this order but the new text was eventually prepared and received royal approval in 1585 by [[Henry III of France]].
There are two reasons why the Coutume reformée might be thought to have little relevance to [[Jersey]]: it was created 380 years after Jersey had ceased formally to be part of the [[Duchy of Normandy]] and it was a text sanctioned by the king of France. Nonetheless, Jersey lawyers and courts made frequent references to the Coutume reformée and by virtue of its assimilation into Jersey law over the centuries it is regarded as a source of the island's law.<ref>{{Cite book | last = Nicolle | first = Stéphanie C | authorlink = | title = The Origin and Development of Jersey Law: an outline guide | publisher = Jersey and Guernsey Law Review Ltd | series = | volume = | edition = 5th | year = 2009 | location = | pages = | language = | url = | doi = | id = | isbn =978-0-9557611-3-3 | mr = | zbl = | jfm = }}</ref>
Commentators on the Coutume reformée include: * [[:fr:Henri Basnage de Franquesnay|Henri Basnage de Franquesnay]]<ref>''[https://books.google.com/books?id=PWxDAAAAcAAJ&dq=inauthor%3AHenri%20inauthor%3ABasnage&pg=PP5#v=onepage&q&f=false Les Œuvres de maître Henri Basnage contenant ses commentaires sur la Coutume de Normandie, et son Traité des hypothèques]'' (Rouen, Maurry, 1709).</ref> * [[Jacques Bathelier d’Aviron]] * [[Josias Bérault]]<ref>(with Godefroy and d'Aviron), ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=otJDAAAAcAAJ&dq=inauthor%3AJosias%20inauthor%3AB%C3%A9rault&pg=PA955#v=onepage&q&f=false Coutumes du pays et duché de Normandie : anciens ressorts & enclaves d’icelui, augmentées de plusieurs edits, déclarations, arrêts & nouveaux réglemens, tant du Conseil que de la Cour, rendus jusqu’à present, comme il est marqué en la table du recueil à la suite de celle des titres ci-après ; & en outre, les articles rectifiez par les textes d’Aviron & de Berault. Avec les extraits sommaires des edits, declarations, ordonnances & arrêts concernans les mariages ; et d’une table des matières, tant pour la coûtume que pour les articles placitez. articles placitez]'', Rouen, Chez Pierre le Boucher, 1731</ref> * [[Jean-Baptiste Flaust]]<ref>''Explication de la coutume et de la jurisprudence de Normandie, dans un ordre simple et facile'', Rouen, Flaust, 1781</ref> * [[Jacques Godefroy]] * [[David Hoüard]]<ref>''[https://books.google.com/books?id=oVJDAAAAcAAJ&dq=inauthor%3ADavid%20inauthor%3AHo%C3%BCard&pg=PP13#v=onepage&q&f=false Dictionnaire analytique, historique, étymologique, critique et interprétatif de la coutume de Normandie, ou l’on trouve la résolution des questions les plus intéressantes du droit civil & ecclésiastique de cette province, conformément à la jurisprudence des arrêts]'', Rouen, Le Boucher le jeune, 1780</ref> * [[Charles Routier]].<ref>''[https://books.google.com/books?id=93EPAAAAQAAJ&dq=inauthor%3Acharles%20inauthor%3Aroutier&pg=PP7#v=onepage&q&f=false Principes généraux du droit civil et coutumier de la province de Normandie : contenant les régles générales & particuliéres, tirées du texte de cette coutume & des réglemens de la court, donnez en interprétation d’icelle, suivant leur ordre naturel. Rédigées sur trois objets. Des personnes, des choses, & des actions]'', Rouen, Pierre Le Boucher, 1748.</ref>
Within France, customary law was abolished in 1804 with the introduction of uniform [[Napoleonic code|codes]] of civil and criminal law across the whole of France.
==== Jersey commentators on custom ==== As well as relying on commentaries produced in France, Jersey has an indigenous legal literature on custom. In the 17th century, [[Jean Poingdestre]] (1609–1691) and [[Philippe Le Geyt]] (1635–1716) wrote several works. Some chapters of [[Charles Sydney Le Gros|C.S. Le Gros]]' 20th century work, ''Traité du Droit Coutumier d l'Ile de Jersey'' also remain relevant.<ref>{{cite book|first=C.S.|last=Le Gros|title=Traité du Droit Coutumier d l'Ile de Jersey|location=St Helier|publisher=Jersey and Guernsey Law Review Ltd|year=1943|ISBN=978-0-9557611-0-2}}</ref>
==== Legislative reforms of custom ==== Many rules of customary law have been amended or abolished by legislation in the later 19th and 20th centuries. Examples of this include: * “Any rule of customary law, that a contract passed before the Royal Court for the transfer of immovable property may be annulled, at the instance of the heirs or devisees, as the case may be, of the transferor, if he or she dies within 40 days of the passing of the contract, is abolished” (Customary Law Amendment (No. 2) (Jersey) Law 1984). * In customary law, the age of majority was 20 years; the Age of Majority (Jersey) Law 1999 reduces this to 18 years. * “The rule under customary law that all gifts to a concubine are null is hereby abolished” (Wills and Successions (Jersey) Law 1993). * Customary law did not permit a cause of action for/against a person to survive the person’s death against/for the benefit of the person’s estate; Customary Law Amendment (Jersey) Law 1948 reversed this situation. * The ''année de jouissance'' (the right of an executor to have the income arising during the administration of a moveable estate for a year and a day) was abolished by the Wills and Successions (Jersey) Law 1993.
=== Influence of English and French law === Some fields of Jersey, such as negligence and administrative law, are heavily influenced by [[English common law#Common law|English common law]]. In other branches of law, notably contract, Jersey courts may have regard to [[French civil law]].<ref>{{cite web|publisher=Jersey Law Commission |title=Consultation Paper No. 5: The Jersey Law of Contract |date=October 2002 |url=http://www.lawcomm.gov.je/Contract.htm }}<BR>{{cite web|publisher=Institute of Law |title=Study Guide on Jersey Contract Law |url=http://www.lawinstitute.ac.je/default.asp?contentID=629 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131228104105/http://www.lawinstitute.ac.je/default.asp?contentID=629 |archivedate=2013-12-28 |df= }}</ref>
=== Human rights === The Human Rights (Jersey) Law 2000,<ref name="HRLaw"/> based closely on the United Kingdom's [[Human Rights Act 1998]], requires Jersey courts so far as possible to interpret legislation so that it is compatible with rights and freedoms guaranteed by the [[European Convention on Human Rights]]. Jersey public bodies are required to act in conformity with Convention rights.
In January 2012, Jersey introduced laws to recognise same-sex civil partnerships.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-jersey-16536572 | work=BBC News | title=Jersey recognises civil partnerships | date=13 January 2012}}</ref>
== Language of Jersey law == During the 20th century, the main working language of the Jersey legal system changed from French to English.<ref>{{cite web|first=Timothy|last=Hanson|title=The Language of Law: the importance of French|year=2005|publisher=Jersey Law Review|url=http://www.jerseylaw.je/Publications/jerseylawreview/june05/JLR0506_Hanson.aspx|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120316221249/http://www.jerseylaw.je/Publications/jerseylawreview/june05/JLR0506_Hanson.aspx|archivedate=2012-03-16|df=}}</ref> Before the 1930s, almost all legislation passed by the States Assembly was in French. Since then, French is used only where new legislation makes amendments to legislation originally drafted in French.<ref>All legislation is available on the [http://www.jerseylaw.je/ Jersey Law] website.</ref>
The conveyancing of immoveable property was carried out using contracts drafted in French until October 2006,<ref>{{cite web|first=Richard|last=Falle|title=The structure of a pro forma Jersey conveyance|year=2004|publisher=Jersey Law Review|url=http://www.jerseylaw.je/Publications/jerseylawreview/june04/JLR0406_Falle.aspx|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120316221329/http://www.jerseylaw.je/Publications/jerseylawreview/june04/JLR0406_Falle.aspx|archivedate=2012-03-16|df=}}<BR>{{cite web|first=David|last=Trotter|title=Commentary on Jersey Conveyance|year=2005|publisher=Jersey Law Review|url=http://www.jerseylaw.je/Publications/jerseylawreview/june05/JLR0506_Trotter.aspx|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120316221404/http://www.jerseylaw.je/Publications/jerseylawreview/june05/JLR0506_Trotter.aspx|archivedate=2012-03-16|df=}}</ref> after which contracts were required to be in English.<ref>{{cite web|first=Richard|last=Falle|title=At the stroke of a pen …|year=2007|publisher=Jersey and Guernsey Law Review|url=http://www.jerseylaw.je/Publications/jerseylawreview/feb07/JLR0702_Falle.aspx#page83|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120316221411/http://www.jerseylaw.je/Publications/jerseylawreview/feb07/JLR0702_Falle.aspx#page83|archivedate=2012-03-16|df=}}</ref> Several French [[Jersey Legal French|words and expressions]] used in Jersey differ from [[Standard French]].
==Precedent and law reporting== [[File:Tables des Décisions de La Cour Royale de Jersey.jpg|thumb|''Tables de Décisions de la Cour Royal de Jersey'' 1885-1978]] The Jersey legal system does not follow the strict rules of [[binding precedent]] that exist in common law jurisdictions such as [[English law|England and Wales]].<ref>''Qatar v Al Thani'' 1999 Jersey Law Reports 118.</ref> The [[Courts of Jersey#Royal Court|Royal Court]] is not bound by its own previous decisions on a point of law but it will generally follow them unless persuaded that the earlier decision was wrongly decided. A similar approach is taken by the [[Courts of Jersey#Appeal courts|Court of Appeal]]. All Jersey courts are, however, bound by points of law decided by the [[Judicial Committee of the Privy Council]] in previous Jersey appeals to that court.
During the 19th and 20th centuries a series of improvements to the system of writing and reporting judgments was put in place. In 1885, the [[Royal Court of Jersey|Royal Court]] began to publish the ''Tables des Décisions de la Cour Royal de Jersey''–a subject index to decided cases, prepared by the [[Greffier]].<ref>Institute of Law, Jersey, ''Jersey Legal System and Constitutional Law'' (2011), chapter 1.</ref>
In 1950, [[Charles Thomas Le Quesne]] [[Queen's Counsel|KC]] returned to Jersey from practice at the [[Barristers in England and Wales|English Bar]] and was appointed [[Lieutenant Bailiff of Jersey|Lieutenant Bailiff]]. Up to this point, the [[Royal Court of Jersey|Royal Court]]'s judgments were in the French style of ''jugements motivés'',{{French spelling}} written in French by the [[Greffier]] rather than the judge, and expressing the reasons for the court's decision only very briefly. Le Quesne changed the language of judgments to English and adopted the [[common law]] style of judgments, where the judge gives detailed reasons for accepting or rejecting the rival submissions made at trial by [[counsel]].<ref>''Attorney General v Weston'' 1979 Jersey Judgments 141.</ref> Between 1950 and 1984, the Royal Court published its and the Court of Appeal judgments in a series of [[law reports]] known as the ''Jersey Judgments'' (eleven volumes in total). From 1984, judgments have been published a new series of [[law reports]] known as the ''Jersey Law Reports''.<ref>Law Reports International Ltd {{cite web |url=http://www.lawreports.com/jersey.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-08-27 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120123022208/http://www.lawreports.com/jersey.htm |archivedate=2012-01-23 |df= }}</ref>
In 2004, the Jersey Legal Information Board (JLIB) was set up to promote "accessibility of the written law and legal processes to the public and of an integrated and efficient legal system, through the use of information technology and by other means".<ref>Jersey Legal Information Board (Incorporation) Law 2004 {{cite web |url=http://www.jerseylaw.je/Law/display.aspx?url=lawsinforce%2fconsolidated%2f16%2f16.335_JerseyLegalInformationBoard%28Incorporation%29Law2004_RevisedEdition_1January2006.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2017-05-12 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303181215/http://www.jerseylaw.je/Law/display.aspx?url=lawsinforce%2Fconsolidated%2F16%2F16.335_JerseyLegalInformationBoard%28Incorporation%29Law2004_RevisedEdition_1January2006.htm |archivedate=2016-03-03 |df= }}</ref> Judgments of the Royal Court and Court of Appeal are published online on [https://web.archive.org/web/20120929022406/http://www.jerseylaw.je/Search/default.aspx?target=uj www.jerseylaw.je], with open access to "unreported" judgments as part of the [[Free Access to Law Movement]].
== Judiciary == The head of the [[Judiciary of Jersey (list)|judiciary in Jersey]] is the [[Bailiff of Jersey|Bailiff]], who as well as performing the judicial functions of a [[chief justice]] is also the President ([[Speaker (politics)|presiding officer]]) of the [[legislature|States of Jersey]] and has certain civic, ceremonial and executive functions. The Bailiff's functions may be exercised by the [[Judiciary of Jersey (list)#Deputy Bailiffs of Jersey|Deputy Bailiff]].
=== Judicial appointments processes === The posts of Bailiff and [[Judiciary of Jersey (list)#Deputy Bailiffs of Jersey|Deputy Bailiff]] are Crown appointments, formally made by Her Majesty the Queen, on [[Politics of Jersey#The Crown|advice]] of the UK government's [[Secretary of State for Justice]].
[[File:Juges Jour d'la Libéthâtion 2009 a.jpg|thumb|The Bailiff and Jurats outside the Royal Court in 2009]]An appointment process has developed in recent years, without a legislative basis, for vacancies for the [[Judiciary of Jersey (list)#Deputy Bailiffs of Jersey|Deputy Bailiff]], Attorney General for Jersey and Solicitor General for Jersey. This involves advertising for candidates and the preparation of a shortlist by a selection panel consisting of the Bailiff (in the chair), the senior [[Jurat]] and the chairman of the [[Jersey Appointments Commission]]. A process of consultation is then carried out, including the Jurats, the [[States Consultative Panel]] (which includes the [[Chief Minister of Jersey|Chief Minister]]), a number of elected members of the States, senior lawyers (the [[Bâtonnier]], the President of the Law Society, the former President of the [[Law Society of Jersey]] and the President of the [[Chambre des Ecrivains]]), the other Crown Officers and the local [[Judiciary of Jersey (list)#Commissioners|Commissioner]] of the [[Courts of Jersey#Royal Court|Royal Court]]. All candidates on the shortlist are then interviewed by the selection panel. A single name is then sent by the Lieutenant Governor to the Secretary of State for Justice.<ref>{{cite web|title=Evidence of Mr M Birt (Bailiff), public hearing 4 May 2010|pages=5–15|publisher=Review of the Roles of the Crown Officers|url=http://www.gov.je/SiteCollectionDocuments/Government%20and%20administration/R%20Bailiff%20Transcript%2020100504%20WM.pdf}}</ref>
This process has not been used for appointment to the office of Bailiff on the basis that "The Secretary of State has accepted that the position of Deputy Bailiff is a training ground for the position of Bailiff, and that, therefore, all things being equal, you would expect to move up, assuming of course that you have performed to everyone's satisfaction".<ref>{{cite web|title=Evidence of Mr M Birt (Bailiff), public hearing 4 May 2010|page=14|publisher=Review of the Roles of the Crown Officers|url=http://www.gov.je/SiteCollectionDocuments/Government%20and%20administration/R%20Bailiff%20Transcript%2020100504%20WM.pdf}}</ref>
[[Jurat]]s are elected by an [[electoral college]] consisting of the Bailiff, the Jurats, the [[Constable#Channel Islands|Connétables]], the elected members of the states, advocates and solicitors of the Royal Court.<ref name="RoyalCourtLaw">Article 4 of the {{cite web|title=Royal Court (Jersey) Law 1948|url=http://www.jerseylaw.je/law/display.aspx?url=lawsinforce%2fconsolidated%2f07%2f07.770_RoyalCourtLaw1948_RevisedEdition_1January2011.htm#Toc268785111|publisher=JerseyLaw|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120316221620/http://www.jerseylaw.je/law/display.aspx?url=lawsinforce%2Fconsolidated%2F07%2F07.770_RoyalCourtLaw1948_RevisedEdition_1January2011.htm#Toc268785111|archivedate=2012-03-16|df=}}</ref> Voting is by secret ballot.
Commissioners of the Royal Court are appointed by the Bailiff for the hearing of a specified cause or matter or a specified term.<ref name="RoyalCourtLawII">Part II of the {{cite web|title=Royal Court (Jersey) Law 1948|url=http://www.jerseylaw.je/law/display.aspx?url=lawsinforce%2fconsolidated%2f07%2f07.770_RoyalCourtLaw1948_RevisedEdition_1January2011.htm#Toc268785122|publisher=JerseyLaw|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120316221620/http://www.jerseylaw.je/law/display.aspx?url=lawsinforce%2Fconsolidated%2F07%2F07.770_RoyalCourtLaw1948_RevisedEdition_1January2011.htm#Toc268785122|archivedate=2012-03-16|df=}}</ref>
The Bailiff appoints the [[Courts of Jersey#Magistrate's Court|Magistrate]] and the Assistant Magistrate (who hold full-time salaried posts) and part-time Relief Magistrates (legal practitioners who carry out duties on a daily fee-paid basis).<ref>{{cite web|title=Loi (1864) concernant la charge de Juge d’Instruction|url=http://www.jerseylaw.je/law/display.aspx?url=lawsinforce%2fconsolidated%2f07%2f07.525_Loi%281864%29ConcernantLaChargeDeJugeD%2527Instruction_RevisedEdition_1January2012.htm|publisher=JerseyLaw}}</ref> It is now normal for the Bailiff to convene a panel to advise on salaried appointments.<ref>{{cite web|title=Evidence of Mr M Birt (Bailiff), public hearing 4 May 2010|pages=17–18|publisher=Review of the Roles of the Crown Officers|url=http://www.gov.je/SiteCollectionDocuments/Government%20and%20administration/R%20Bailiff%20Transcript%2020100504%20WM.pdf}}</ref>
===Removal from office=== The Bailiff, Deputy Bailiff and members of the [[Jersey Court of Appeal]] 'hold office during good behaviour'.<ref>In relation to the Court of Appeal: {{cite web|title=Court of Appeal (Jersey) Law 1961|url=http://www.jerseylaw.je/Law/display.aspx?url=lawsinforce%2fconsolidated%2f07%2f07.245_CourtofAppealLaw1961_RevisedEdition_1January2010.htm#Toc249951726|publisher=JerseyLaw|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120316221706/http://www.jerseylaw.je/Law/display.aspx?url=lawsinforce%2Fconsolidated%2F07%2F07.245_CourtofAppealLaw1961_RevisedEdition_1January2010.htm#Toc249951726|archivedate=2012-03-16|df=}}</ref> Whereas senior judges in England and Wales who are appointed by Crown may only be removed from office with the consent of both Houses of Parliament,<ref>{{cite web|title=Senior Courts Act (previously known as the Supreme Court Act) 1981, section 11(3)|url=http://www.legislation.gov.uk/ukpga/1981/54/section/11|publisher=Legislation.gov.uk}}<BR>{{cite web|url=http://www.judiciary.gov.uk/about-the-judiciary/the-judiciary-in-detail/jud-acc-ind/judges-and-parliament|title=Judges and parliament|publisher=Judiciary of England and Wales}}</ref> the United Kingdom [[Secretary of State for Justice]] may dismiss a Jersey judge appointed by the Crown without the agreement [[States of Jersey]]. This happened in 1992, when the then Deputy Bailiff [[Vernon Tomes]] was dismissed from office by the [[Home Secretary]] (the UK minister who at the time was responsible for the [[Crown Dependencies]]) on grounds of his delays in producing written judgments.<ref>{{cite web|publisher=House of Commons|title=Debates vol 208 cc93-4W|date=19 May 1992|url=http://hansard.millbanksystems.com/written_answers/1992/may/19/jersey-bailiff-dismissal#S6CV0208P0_19920519_CWA_184}}<BR>{{cite news|last=Dyer|title='Dismissal of "slow" Judge angers Jersey|newspaper=The Guardian|date=13 May 1992}}<BR>{{cite news|first=Nick|last=Cohen|title=Jersey in revolt after Clarke sacks judge|newspaper=The Independent|date=13 May 1992}}<BR>{{cite news|first=Nick|last=Cohen|title=Jersey to review constitutional links with UK|newspaper=The Independent|date=14 May 1992}}</ref>
Jurats hold office up to the age of 72 years. A Jurat who 'in the opinion of the Court, is permanently unable, through physical or mental incapacity, or for any other reason, efficiently to carry out the duties of the office, may be called upon by the Court to resign'. A Jurat who refuses to resign may be removed from office by Order of Her Majesty in Council on the petition of the Superior Number (the Bailiff and five or more Jurats) of the [[Courts of Jersey#Royal Court|Royal Court]].<ref>Article 9 of the Royal Court (Jersey) Law 1948</ref>
The Bailiff may if he 'thinks fit, terminate the appointment of a Commissioner on the ground of incapacity or misbehaviour'.<ref name="RoyalCourtLawII"/>
The Magistrates, who are also appointed by the Bailiff not the Crown, may not be removed from office 'except by virtue of an Order of Her Majesty in Council'.<ref>Article 2(3) of the {{cite web|title=Loi (1864) concernant la charge de Juge ===Judicial independence in Jersey===
====Code of Conduct==== All judges in Jersey are bound by a [http://www.gov.je/Government/NonexecLegal/BailiffsChambers/Pages/CodeConduct.aspx code of conduct] promulgated by the [[Jersey Judicial Association]] in 2007. This requires judges to 'uphold the integrity and independence of the judiciary and perform their duties with competence, diligence and dedication'.<ref>{{cite web|title=Code of conduct for members of the judiciary of Jersey, paragraph 1|year=2007|url=http://www.gov.je/Government/NonexecLegal/BailiffsChambers/Pages/CodeConduct.aspx|publisher=Jersey Government}}</ref>
====ECHR Article 6==== All courts in Jersey are required under [[Article 6 of the European Convention on Human Rights]] to be 'independent and impartial'.<ref name="HRLaw"/> In 2000, the [[European Court of Human Rights]] held in ''McGonnell v United Kingdom''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bailii.org/eu/cases/ECHR/2000/62.html|title=McGonnell v United Kingdom (2000) ECHR 62|publisher=British and Irish Legal Information Institute}}</ref> that there was a breach of Article 6 in ''Guernsey'' where the Bailiff or Deputy Bailiff sat as President of the [[States of Guernsey]] when proposed legislation was being debated and then subsequently sat as a judge of the [[Royal Court of Guernsey]] in a case where that legislation was relevant. The Court, noting that there was no suggestion that the Bailiff 'was subjectively biased', stated that the 'mere fact' that this happened was capable of casting doubt on the Bailiff's impartiality. A Bailiff and Deputy Bailiff in Jersey is able to avoid a ''McGonnell'' situation simply by not sitting in the [[Royal Court of Jersey|Royal Court]] in cases concerned with legislation that was debated when he presided in the [[States of Jersey|States]]. The current Bailiff, Mr [[Michael Birt (Bailiff of Jersey)|Michael Birt]] has conceded that 'we probably need to improve our systems to be very compliant with ''McGonnell'' and that one probably ought to keep a running list of those statutes where I have presided so at least I could invite the parties to consider whether they wanted to object or not'.<ref>Pages 46-47, Review of the Roles of the Crown Officers, Public Hearing 4 May 2010</ref> In a recent review chaired by [[Lord Carswell]], set up by the [[States of Jersey]], a legal opinion was commissioned from [[Rabinder Singh (Barrister)|Rabinder Singh]] QC in which he expressed the view that 'there is no reason in law why the present constitutional arrangements in respect of the Bailiff should be altered. However, the trend suggests that the tide of history is in favour of reform and that the legal position will be different in 10 years time'.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gov.je/Government/Pages/StatesReports.aspx?ReportID=491|title=Report into Review of Crown Officers|publisher=Jersey Government|date=6 December 2010}}</ref> The report of Lord Carswell's inquiry concluded that Mr Singh's opinion 'provides an additional reason why the Bailiff should cease to be the President of the States'.<ref>Para 5.16 of Report into Review of Crown Officers</ref> The [[States of Jersey]] have not accepted this aspect of the Carswell report. Many prominent islanders do not believe that any change is necessary or desirable.<ref>See e.g. {{cite web|first=Reg|last=Jeune|title=Let's not throw out 800 years of history and good governance|publisher=Jersey Evening Post|date=20 December 2010|url=http://www.thisisjersey.com/2010/12/20/lets-not-throw-out-800-years-of-history-and-good-governance/}}<BR>{{cite web|url=http://www.gov.je/Government/HowGovernmentWorks/ReviewCrownOfficers/Pages/WrittenSubmissions.aspx|title=Written submissions on role of Crown Officers|publisher=Review of the Roles of the Crown Officers}}</ref>
====Stuart Syvret litigation==== In recent years, a former [[States of Jersey|State's]] member Mr [[Stuart Syvret]] has argued in legal proceedings in England and Jersey that all members of [[Judiciary of Jersey (list)|the Jersey judiciary]] lack the appearance of independence and impartiality. In March 2009, the High Court in London refused him permission to commence a judicial review claim against [[Home Secretary]] [[Jack Straw]].<ref>{{cite news |url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/europe/jersey/7946988.stm |title=Jersey abuse case review rejected |first= |last=Anon|work=[[BBC News]] |date=17 March 2009 |publisher=[[BBC]] |location=[[London, England|London]] |accessdate=5 September 2011}}; {{cite web |url= http://www.channelonline.tv/channelonline_jerseynews/displayarticle.asp?id=400612 |title=Syvret loses High Court bid |first= |last=Anon |work=channelonline.tv |date=17 March 2009 |accessdate=5 September 2011}}</ref> In Jersey, subsequent proceedings related to a criminal prosecution for a data protection offence (he named a former nurse on his [[blog]], who he said was guilty of murdering patients), judicial reviews and appeals relating to that criminal case, and a separate civil action brought by Syvret against fellow politicians and Law Officers in connection with his removal from office as minister for health.<ref>See, for example:<BR>{{cite news|title=Nursing a grievance in Jersey|newspaper=Private Eye (no 1288)|date=13 May 2011|page=30}}<BR>{{cite news|title=Former Jersey senator jailed over data-breach blog|newspaper=The Daily Telegraph|date=19 November 2010|page=11}}<BR>{{cite news|title=Hemming shields man|newspaper=Birmingham Evening Mail|date=26 October 2009|page=8}} (referring to Liberal Democrat MP [[John Hemming (politician)|John Hemming]]'s assistance to Syvret)<BR>{{cite news|first=Andrew|last=Hough|title=Jersey senator to claim asylum at Commons|newspaper=The Daily Telegraph|date=26 October 2009|page=16}}<BR>{{cite news|title=Charge against senator in abuse cover-up claim|newspaper=The Times|date=20 July 2009|page=26}}</ref> Syvret argues that he cannot have a fair trial in the island and there is a lack of appearance of independence and impartiality because judges are appointed by the [[Bailiff (Channel Islands)|Bailiff]] and the other judges have attended social events with the Bailiff. Syvret's arguments relating to lack of independence and impartiality have been rejected by the Royal Court and Court of Appeal in Jersey on a number of occasions between 2009 and 2011.<ref>Judgment of == Jersey legal profession == [[File:Institute of Law, St Helier, Jersey.jpg|thumb|Institute of Law, Seale Street, St Helier|upright]]The Jersey legal profession has three types of Jersey-qualified lawyers - Advocates, Solicitors and [[Public notary#United Kingdom|Notaries Public]].<ref name="1997Law">{{cite web|url=http://www.jerseylaw.je/Law/display.aspx?url=lawsinforce%2fconsolidated%2f07%2f07.070_AdvocatesandSolicitorsLaw1997_RevisedEdition_1January2009.htm#Toc203181030|title=Advocates and Solicitors Law 1997|publisher=JerseyLaw|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120316221753/http://www.jerseylaw.je/Law/display.aspx?url=lawsinforce%2fconsolidated%2f07%2f07.070_AdvocatesandSolicitorsLaw1997_RevisedEdition_1January2009.htm#Toc203181030|archivedate=2012-03-16|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.legislation.gov.uk/ukpga/Vict/6-7/90|title=Public Notaries Act 1843}} (United Kingdom), section 4</ref> [[Advocate#Advocates in the Channel Islands|Advocates]] have rights of audience to represent clients in all courts. Jersey solicitors have no general rights of audience. Notaries have no rights of audience. The Law Society of Jersey<ref>[http://www.jerseylawsociety.je/ Law Society of Jersey ]</ref> is the professional body responsible for professional conduct. Notaries are regulated by the Faculty Office of the Archbishop of Canterbury through the [[Dean of the Arches]], referred to as the [[Master of the Faculties]], who is normally an English [[Queen's Counsel|QC]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.facultyoffice.org.uk|title=Faculty Office}}</ref>
Some law firms focus on legal practice relating to Jersey's [[Economy of Jersey#Financial .26 legal services|finance industry]], the largest being: [[Appleby Spurling Hunter|Appleby]]; Bedell Cristin; [[Carey Olsen]]; [[Mourant Ozannes]]; and [[Ogier (law firm)|Ogier]], all of which are regarded as part of the "[[offshore magic circle]]". Smaller firms and sole practitioners also provide a wide range of legal services.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.jerseylawsociety.je/lawfirms.htm|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110613012913/http://www.jerseylawsociety.je/lawfirms.htm|dead-url=yes|archive-date=2011-06-13|title=Law Firms|publisher=Law Society of Jersey}}</ref> Several law firms now have offices in both Jersey and [[Guernsey]] but the legal professions of the two islands are separate, as they are separate from those in England, Wales and Scotland. Most notaries in Jersey are employed by, or are partners in, local firms of Jersey Advocates or Solicitors, although some are in English solicitors firms or practising purely as notaries, independent of the general legal profession. There is a local Jersey Notaries Society.
The Law Officers of the Crown are responsible for criminal prosecution work and for providing legal advice to the Crown, ministers and other members of the Assembly of the [[States of Jersey]]. The Attorney General and his deputy, the Solicitor General, are non-voting members of the States Assembly.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gov.je/Government/NonexecLegal/LawOfficers/Pages/index.aspx|title=Law Officers|publisher=Jersey Government}}</ref>
The process of qualifying as a Jersey lawyer is regulated by the Advocates and Solicitors (Jersey) Law 1997<ref name="1997Law"/> and is similar for both advocates and solicitors. Since 2009, candidates for the [[Jersey law]] examinations are required to enrol on the Jersey Law Course run by the Institute of Law, Jersey.<ref>[http://www.lawinstitute.ac.je/ Institute of Law]</ref> They are required to take five compulsory papers: (i) Jersey legal system and constitutional Law; (ii) Law of contract and the law relating to security on moveable property and bankruptcy; (iii) testate and intestate succession; law of immoveable property and conveyancing; and civil and criminal procedure. In addition, candidates must take one of three option papers: (i) company law; (ii) trusts law; or (iii) family law.
The admission of lawyers as Notaries in Jersey is governed by an order of the [[Master of the Faculties]]. It is necessary to show that a prospective Notary has been in actual practise in Jersey as a Jersey-qualified Advocate or Solicitor for a period of 5 years and is required to pass an examination in Notarial Practice. The Master does however retain a discretion to admit those who are not so qualified "...in appropriate circumstances".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.facultyoffice.org.uk/TheNotaries%28JerseyandGuernsey%29AdmissionOrder2012.pdf|title=The Notaries (Jersey and Guernsey) Admission Order 2012|publisher=Faculty Office|date=5 December 2012}}</ref>
== Legal aid == There is no publicly funded [[legal aid]] system in Jersey, though the [[States of Jersey]] may exercise discretion to pay defence legal fees in serious criminal trials<ref>{{cite web|title=A system in need of overhaul|publisher=Jersey Evening Post|date=15 September 2010|url=http://jerseyeveningpost.com/news/2010/09/15/a-system-in-need-of-overhaul/}}.<BR>{{cite web|first=Elaine|last=Byrne|title=£3m cost may lead to legal aid review|publisher=Jersey Evening Post|date=21 October 2009|url=http://jerseyeveningpost.com/news/2009/10/21/3m-cost-may-lead-to-legal-aid-review/}}</ref> and in cases involving children.<ref>{{cite web|first=Dolores|last=Cowburn|title=Serious case review cost the Island over £600,000|publisher=Jersey Evening Post|date=15 September 2010|url=http://www.thisisjersey.com/2010/09/15/serious-case-review-cost-the-island-over-600000/}}<BR>{{cite web|title=The Bailiff champions welfare of children|publisher=Jersey Evening Post|date=1 July 2008|url=http://www.thisisjersey.com/2008/07/01/the-bailiff-champions-welfare-of-children/}}</ref> During their first 15 years of practice, Jersey Advocates and Solicitors, but not Notaries, are required to participate in a scheme organised by the profession to ensure so far as possible that people without sufficient resources are not prevented from pursuing or defending civil and criminal cases in the island's courts. The scheme is administered on behalf by the [[Bâtonnier]] (a senior member of the profession). Cases accepted by the Bâtonnier as eligible are allocated to lawyers on the basis of the 'Tour de Rôle' (i.e. according to one's turn). Depending on the litigants' income and assets, lawyers may work [[pro bono]] or charge a reasonable fee in accordance with published guidelines.<ref>{{cite web|publisher=Jersey Citizen's Advice Bureau|title=Legal Aid|url=http://www.cab.org.je/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=106&Itemid=66}}</ref> A lawyer assigned a legal aid case may choose to pay another lawyer to handle the case and several firms have established specialist legal aid departments.<ref>{{cite web|first=Harry|last=McRandle|title=Law firm stops taking legal aid divorce cases|publisher=Jersey Evening Post|date=5 November 2005|url=http://www.thisisjersey.com/2005/11/05/law-firm-stops-taking-legal-aid-divorce-cases/}}</ref> There have been numerous and long-standing calls for reform of the present system.<ref>{{cite web|first=Ben|last=Quérée|title=Public should pay for legal aid, says Bailiff|publisher=Jersey Evening Post|date=14 September 2007|url=http://www.thisisjersey.com/2007/09/14/public-should-pay-for-legal-aid-says-bailiff/}}<BR>{{cite web|first=Andy|last=Sibcy|title=Taxpayers "may have to foot bill for legal aid"|publisher=Jersey Evening Post|date=12 September 2003|url=http://www.thisisjersey.com/2003/09/12/taxpayers-may-have-to-foot-bill-for-legal-aid/}}</ref>
== Law reform == The Jersey Law Commission<ref>[http://www.lawcomm.gov.je/ Jersey Law Commission]</ref> was established by the [[States of Jersey]] in 1996 to keep Jersey [[Law commission|law under review]] and bring forward proposals for law reform.
